Having fully repaid her previous loan of 5000 from PMP, she is now requesting a new loan, her fourth, of 6000  from PMPC to buy fertilizer.

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Mrs. Phalla N. and her husband, Mr. Vit Sou (pictured together), live along National Road Number One about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh city. They  married in 1987 and have seven children: four sons and three daughters. One daughter works in a garment factory and the other children are in school. Besides her children, Mrs. Phalla N. also has her elderly mother living with her. 

Mrs. Phalla has been running a grocery store at her house and selling fruit for more than three years. Mr. Vit Sou is a mason. Phalla used to request Kiva loan several times already, she hopes to continue expanding her business. So, she is asking for another loan in the amount of $1,200 to purchase grocery items for her stock and buy fruit under contract for resale.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for her stock and buy fruit under contract for resale

loans.name: Adelina Vapor's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Adelina V., 55 years of age, married, is a resident of Pulot, Ozamiz City. Adelina is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each of the group receives an individual loan, they are each responsible for paying back the loan of their fellow group member if she is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 'Adelina V.’s Group'. 
	
Adelina is married to Alejandro V., her business partner. They are blessed with 4 children;and now they are all in adult-aged. The couple decided to engage in business by operating a charcoal retail.  For 20 years already, the couple has been able to manage these businesses and now they are earning an average net income of not less than P 6,000 a month, which is very helpful as their family income.

Mrs. V. joined the cooperative in the year 2009. As an active member of the PDP-LP (Paglaum Development Program for Landless People) of PAGLAUM MPC, a micro-finance program that reaches out to the rural poor, she is requesting the amount of P 7,000 as her 2nd loan for the purpose of purchasing additional charcoal to sell. The future income from this loan will be used to improve the living conditions for her family, to meet their basic needs, as savings for future use, and for children’s education. She is hoping that someday her business will become more progressive.

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase additional charcoal to sell

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros B., 62, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Clemente B., she is blessed with one child in their marriage. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been selling herbal health supplements for quite some time now.

Milagros has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 17,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying more quantities of her products so she can supply to more customers.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide a comfortable and well-off life for her family.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying more quantities of her products so she can supply to more customers

loans.name: Chantha

texts.en:
Mrs. Chantha L., 40 (pictured here), and her husband, Mr. Vy Ngoun, 47, have been married for 18 years and have six children: four sons and two daughters. One daughter is a garment factory worker and the other children are in school. The family lives aL. National Road Number Five about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Chantha has been selling corn for five years, while her husband has been a construction worker for four years. Besides the businesses, the couple also grow rice on their farmland in the village. 

Chantha is applying for her first loan in the amount of $650 to purchase a motorized hand tiller to use on her rice farm.

loans.use: To purchase a motorized hand tiller

loans.name: Susan Cinco's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Susan C., 48 years of age and married, is a resident of P3 Manabay, Ozamiz City. Susan is the group leader of a 3-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 'Susan C.’s Group'. 	

Susan is married to Edgar C., a driver with an average net income of P 300 a day. They are blessed with 7 children; one is already married and the rest are still single and in their teenage years. To help her husband in supporting their family, Susan decided to engage in business, particularly in recycling activities.  For 20 years already, she has been able to manage this little business and now she is earning an average net income of not less than P 4,000 a month which is very helpful for their family income.

Susan joined the cooperative just this year. As a new member of the PDP-LP (Paglaum Development Program for Landless People) of PAGLAUM MPC, a micro-finance program that reaches out to the rural poor, she is requesting the amount of P 5,000 as her 1st loan for the purpose of adding to her capital for her existing recycling activity. The future income from this loan will be used to improve the living conditions for her family, to meet their basic needs, as savings for future use, and for their children’s education. 

Susan is hoping that someday her business will become more progressive.

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC)is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her recycling business

loans.name: Criselda

texts.en:
Criselda T. is from the village of San Jose. She is 33 years old. Criselda is married and has 2 young children. To make a living, Criselda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Criselda has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 130,000 PHP every four months.

In 2005, Criselda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Criselda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Criselda is requesting a new loan of 35,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This will be the tenth loan taken out by Criselda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Mr. Pov K. and his wife, Mrs. Sopheap Ny (pictured together), have been married since 2001 and have three sons. Two of them attend school and another one is still young.

Mr. Pov K. a 'Tuk Tuk' motorcycle taxi driver. He carries goods and people from his village to Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia and back. Mrs. Sopheap Ny is a tailor and also runs grocery store. 

Unhappily, Pov’s motorbike is old and does not work properly. It has upset his business and he spends a lot of money for repair costs very often. Facing this, Pov is requesting his second loan in the amount of $1,200 to purchase a new motorbike to replace the old one and buy grocery items for his wife’s stock. Then Pov will not be having to make frequent repairs anymore.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorbike to replace the old one and buy grocery items for his wife’s stock

loans.name: Eunelyn

texts.en:
Eunelyn M. is from the village of Siayan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 21 years old and still single. To make a living, Eunelyn owns & operates a general store, and this is her main source of income. Eunelyn has been engaged in her business for 2 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Eunelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eunelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Eunelyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Eunelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital to buy products to sell

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia B., 32, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. She makes sure that she earns well so that she and her two children can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store for four years.

Virginia B. has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her variety store.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 20,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more quantities of products needed to replenish and maintain operations of the variety store.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying more quantities of products needed to replenish and maintain operations of her variety store

loans.name: Nargis' Group

texts.en:
Nargis is 40 years old, married with six children. She comes from a city called Borewala (famous for its shrines) in Pakistan. She is the mother of six sons. Her eldest son completed his education till 5th standard and then started his own food stand in 2007 where he sells specifically Dahi Bhalas & Daal Chawal (local dishes). Her next son got his education till 8th standard and sits with his father in his grocery shop. 

The next youngest to him is a driver and he couldn’t study because he had no interest in going to school. By the grace of God, the others are enrolled in a school and are getting an education. Nargis specially pays attention to them so they get the education and make their future bright. 

Nargis is a regular client of Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan and a partner of Kiva). She has successfully repaid three loans to Asasah and now she is applying for a loan for the fourth time to purchase groceries such as lentils, cooking oil, rice and spices in bulk to diversify her husband’s grocery shop into a store.

loans.use: Purchase groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Set

texts.en:
Mr. Set L. and his wife, Mrs. Nub Sai, married in 1980 and have six children: three sons and three daughters. Two of them are married and live outside the famiL. home; one daughter is a silk weaver, and another child is a fisherman. The famiL. lives along National Road Number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. Set is not in the photo, but his wife was available instead. 

Mr, Set L. has been a fisherman since he was young. He catches fish from the Mekong River and a lake near his village. Mrs. Nub Sai sells the fish that her husband catches at a local market. He does not have enough fishing materials to operate the business. So, he is requesting his second loan of US$ 600 to purchase fishing nets.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets for his fishing business

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie P. is from the village of Antipolo. She is 44 years old. Elsie is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Elsie owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling ground pork and beef products known as "longganisa". Elsie has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP average a month for these activities.

In 2006, Elsie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to expand her sales of ground pork and beef products. Elsie is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Elsie from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita R., 57, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. She makes sure that she earns well so that she and her two children can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store for quite some time now.

Margarita has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her variety store.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 14,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying groceries needed to replenish and maintain her product inventory and continue operations of her variety store.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow and be successful, providing her and her children a comfortable and well-off future.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying groceries needed to continue operations of her variety store

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily E. is from the town of Solomon. She is 38 years old. Emily is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Emily owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also raises hogs for extra income. Emily has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Emily joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emily is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the first loan taken out by Emily from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business and acquire additional piglets to raise. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure and piglets to raise

loans.name: Elena San Juan's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Elena S. J., 42 years of age, is married and is a resident of P3 Manabay, Ozamiz City. Elena is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Elena S. J.’s Group.

Elena is married to Danilo S. J., a forklift operator with an average net income of P3,600 every 15th and 30th day of the month. They are blessed with six children who are all now in their teens.

To help her husband in supporting their family, Elena decided to engage in a snack-vending business, particularly banana cue (deep-fried banana covered with caramelized brown sugar), and a sari-sari store. For fifteen years already, she has been able to manage this little business and now she is earning an average net income of not less than P1,500 a month which, she said, is so helpful to their family income.

Elena joined Paglaum MPC just this year. As a newly recognized member of the PDP-LP (Paglaum Development Program for Landless People) Program of Paglaum MPC, a micro-finance program that reaches out to the rural poor, she is requesting P3,000 as her first loan to add to the capital of her existing business activity which is her sari-sari store and snack-vending business.

The future income from this loan will be used to improve the living conditions of Elena’s family, to meet their basic needs, and as savings for future use and for house repair. She is hoping that someday her business will become more progressive and that all her children will finish their studies up to college level.


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store and snack-vending business

loans.name: Marriane

texts.en:
Marriane M. is from the town of Banga. She is 33 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children.

Marriane works in someone else's business planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also raises ducks for extra income. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years.

In 2010, Marriane joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies and equipment and also feeds for her ducks. This loan will be her first loan from CEVI.

Marriane plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. 


About CEVI:

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma C., 57, is making sure that her family has enough provision for their daily needs. Married to Leo C., a carpenter, she is blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.

Norma has been managing her own variety store while overseeing operations of their pedicab (a bicycle with a side car that can seat up to three passengers) business.

Norma has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.

To ensure the success of her business, Norma would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying groceries needed to continue the operation of her store.

Norma dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she and her family can experience life’s simple pleasures like delicious food and acquire some material things.

loans.name: Kosar Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Kosar parveen is a 39-year-old married woman who has lived in the city of Borewala (famous for its shrines) in Pakistan for over fourteen years. Her husband’s name is M. R. and he operates a flour-selling business. He has been doing this work for over thirteen years.

Kosar is the mother of six children: three sons and three daughters. Her elder son has completed his education to 10th standard and now works in the police department as an officer. The next in age helps his father in his flour-selling business. The others are enrolled in a school and are getting an education.

Kosar is a very hardworking lady. She operates a quilt-selling business. She sells the quilts to the shops and earns income. She also offers a service filling quilts with cotton for her neighbors. She earns approximately Pak Rs. 10,000 every month.

Kosar is a regular client of Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan and a Kiva partner). She has successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah and now she is applying for a loan for the third time to purchase flour in bulk to expand her husband’s flour-selling business.

loans.use: To purchase flour in bulk for her husband's business

Gleceria owns and operates a general store, selling daily food in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for twenty-five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Gleceria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. loans.name: Mrs. Sinou Hou Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twelve people make up this village bank loan and they are all living in Spean Daek village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sinou H. is the village bank president, selected by all the members. Each member will use their loan for a different purpose.

Mrs. Sinou H. is a farmer who owns a very small piece of land on which she grows rice and vegetables to sell to support her family. Her problem is that her field has infertile soil and it is a long way from the irrigation system. So, to improve production, she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline.

Mrs. Sinou H.’s husband, Mr. Oran Orat, is a fisherman and they have a child who is helping her with the farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more cloth and thread

loans.name: Eufemia

texts.en: Eufemia J. is from the town of Banga. She is 47 years old, is married, and has four school-aged children. Eufemia owns and operates a business planting and harvesting corn for sale. She also runs a small sari-sari (variety) store located at her house. She has been engaged in her businesses for over nine years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Eufemia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure and also additional merchandise for her store. This loan will be her first loan from CEVI. Eufemia plans to use the additional revenue generated from the businesses to improve her businesses. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. loans.name: Aqa Jan Group

texts.en: Parwein leads a loan group called Aqa Jan and lives in Kabul's 15th district. She is married, has four children and works hard as a tailor to earn enough money to meet her family’s needs. She has applied for a loan to buy a new sewing machine because her old one is giving her lots of problems. She will also use a portion of the loan to hire a student to help her with her work and enlarge her business. She wants to thank AFS in Afghanistan for the help it is providing and the chance it is giving her to earn a larger income.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for her shop

loans.name: Felecia

texts.en:
Felecia C. lives in the village of Misom. She is 38 years old, married, has four school-aged children and makes a living by selling dry goods to people in her community. She has been in this line of work for more than five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Felecia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid three previous loans from PMPC, and used them to expand her business. She is applying for a new loan, for 7,000 PHP, to buy additional items to sell in her store.

loans.name: Tsetsegmaa

texts.en: Tsetsegmaa T. is 50 years old and lives with her husband and 17-year-old daughter in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger (or Mongolian nomadic tent). In 1996, she moved from Hovd province to Ulaanbaatar city so that her child could eventually enroll in a university. Between 1996 and 2006, Tsetsegmaa operated a tailoring business from her home. Since 2006, she has made a living selling vegetables at a market called Har Horin. Her business is doing very well, thanks in part to help from her daughter, and her husband earns additional income by running an auto repair service. Tsetsegmaa has many plans for the future, and says, “My aim is to create my own shop by working hard and stabilizing my current business.” She is applying for a loan for 3,000,000 MNT to buy vegetables at wholesales prices to resell to her many customers.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell to her customers

loans.name: Jenny

texts.en:
Jenny F. is a simple woman who dreams of getting her family out of poverty and helping her children enjoy careers of their choice. She also hopes that her husband's fishing business will grow, and help their children attend college and go to work for a business rather than becoming fishermen. Jenny joined ASHI as a way of achieving her dreams, and has applied for and received loans to support her husband's business.

Jenny is now applying for a new, larger loan from ASHI to start a business fattening pigs. Her goal is to augment her husband's small income and build up enough savings to achieve the dream of sending her children to college. She plans to spend four months fattening the animals, which she then plans to sell to people who live in her village.

loans.use: To buy piglets for fattening.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn G. lives in the town of Cabuling. She is 44 years old, married, has three school-aged children and makes a living by raising livestock, especially ducks and pigs. She has been in business for more than 12 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month from her work.

Earlier this year, Jocelyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She is now applying for her first loan, for 6,000 PHP, which which she will use to buy livestock feed and other supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to continue expanding her business. 

About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training through regular group meetings.

loans.name: Mrs. Thach Eam Village Bank Group

texts.en: These fourteen people live in Ping Pong village in Kandal province and they have requested a village bank loan. Mrs. Thach E. is the village bank president, selected by all the members. Each member will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Thach E. is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her children and her husband, Mr. Kao Men, who is a laborer. Although they work hard, their income is low. In order to improve condition her family's living conditions, Mrs. Thach E. is seeking this loan to buy a mother pig to breed, to start a new business. She is a mother of three children who are laborers.

loans.use: To buy a mother pig to breed

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.en:
Consuelo L. is from the village of Olingan, Dipolog City. She is 54 years old. Consuelo is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Consuelo owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Consuelo is just starting this business.

In 2010, Consuelo joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Consuelo is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Consuelo from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is N.R.' Group.

Naida is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Naida owns & operates a "sari-sari" (generalstore) business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Naida has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities. In 2008, Naida joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Naida has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Naida is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Naida from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.name: Mrs. Khim Man Village Bank Group

texts.en: This is a village bank loan which consists of thirteen people who are living in Ping Pong village in Kandal province. They are each going to use the loan for different purposes so that it can improve their business in the future. Mrs. Khim M. is the village bank president, meaning that she has been selected by all the members to lead the group. She is a fish seller at local market and her husband, Mr. Chhey Chhai, is a farmer who owns a plot of land where he cultivates rice to sell to support his family. Her problem is that her rice field is on time to do farming. So to improve rice production, Mrs. Khim M. is seeking to use this loan to do farming in this current year. She is a mother of five children, two of whom are laborers, while the others are attending in local public school.

loans.use: To farm

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
Benjamin C. is a 36 year old farmer and married to Jane Kimaru. They live in Kaptallam and have three children: Mercy (7 years old - in class one), Emmanuel (5 years old, in top class), and Noah Cheboi (baby class).

Benjamin does farming for commercial purposes. He has done this for three years and earns a monthly profit of Kshs 1000. He has borrowed a loan of KSHS 10,000. The entire loan will be used to increase production in the farm by buying more farm inputs.

Benjamin has not borrowed from another source other than KADET LTD and was introduced to the organization by a former KADET client. Benjamin does farming in Kabernet, Kenya, and his customers are very friendly.

If this loan boosts his business, Benjamin will use the extra profit to provide for his family.  He dreams and hopes to be a leading farmer in his community.  Benjamin describes himself as a hardworking born again Christian farmer.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs.

loans.name: Myagmarsuren

texts.en:
Myagmarsuren T., 46, lives with his wife and 18 year old son in Tuv province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger (the Mongolian nomadic tent). They have been living together in their current home for 15 years. His son, Otgonbayr, is a university student in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

Myagmarsuren operates a meat trading business with his wife. He started a mobile meat trading business in 2004 with a working capital of 200,000 MNT, and after several years of successful operations has built a working capital of 2,000,000 MNT. Over the past six years, he has gained much experience as a trader. He currently has 80 heads of livestock, worth a total of about 1,600,000 MNT. With his business profit, he has been paying the university tuition fees for his youngest son. In addition he was able to pay for the university tuition of his other children through to their graduations. Myagmarsuren is a very hard working person. He says, “I am  working hard to expand my business and build a house for my family. ” He is requesting 1,600,000 MNT loan to purchase livestock while it is cheap for 1,000,000 MNT, and other raw materials (such as skins) with the remaining 600,000 MNT.

loans.use: To purchase livestock and inventory.

loans.name: Thomas Kiplagat

texts.en:
Thomas is a single 30 year old man and he lives in a low income village called Kaptallam in Kabernet, Kenya. He is a small scale farmer who began farming 3 years ago and gets a monthly profit of KSHS 2000. Other sources of income give him Kshs 1500 every month. Thomas has borrowed a loan of Kshs 15,000 from  KADET, which he was introduced to by a KADET group in his neighborhood. He will use Kshs 10,000 of his loan to purchase fertilizer and Kshs 5,000 to buy maize seeds.

If this loan boosts his business, he will use the extra profit to expand his business. He dreams and hopes to have a big and stable business. Thomas describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs.

loans.name: Joi's Group

texts.en:
Joi A. is from the village of Northern. She is 37 years old. Joi is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Joi is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Joi owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling of "Longganisa" processed meat in the local community. Joi has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Joi joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joi has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Joi is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 15th loan taken out by Joi from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living standards of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Tsetsgee

texts.en:
Tsetsgee M., 49, is married and the mother of three children. She and her family live together in a 'ger' (the Mongolian nomadic tent) in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Tsetsgee operates a meat trading business. She moved with her family from Tuv province to Ulaanbaatar city in 1998 in order to find work and provide a better life for her family. 

Tsetsgee started her business with a working capital of 500,000 MNT in 1999 at the Har Horin market. Since that time she has steadily expanded her business and today has a working capital of 3,000,000 MNT. Her family and business are both very important for her. Her husband, Enhtaivan, operates a taxi service. One of her sons is a performer in a circus, and Tsetsgee's 10-year-old youngest daughter attends a local primary school. She is a very hard-working person. 

Tsetsgee says, “My two sons have both graduated from their university, which was so important to me. Now I am concentrating on building my own shop and expanding my business.” She is requesting a 1,300,000 MNT loan to purchase horse meat to resell to her customers before prices increase.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Apostol

texts.en:
Apostol T. is from the village of San Jose. He is 46 years old. Apostol is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Apostol owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not his only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Apostol has been engaged in his business for over 30 years and earns approximately 90000 PHP per harvest.

In 2005, Apostol joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Apostol has successfully repaid a previous loan of 33000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Apostol is requesting a new loan of 35000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Apostol from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Florah

texts.en:
Florah C. was born in 1962.  She is married to Kimaloi Kiptui who is a 58-year-old farmer. Her farm is in Kipsaraman- Koyoin in Kabernet, Kenya.  She has 7 children, and amongst them are Kipkoech (29  years; Information Technology Officer), Barnabas (28 years old; a banker), Lillian (23 years old; an O-level graduate, works in the judiciary), Samson (20 years old; a teacher), Enock (16 years old; in high school), and Jebet ( 8 years old; in Standard Four).

Florah is a fruit farmer.  She started this venture eighteen years ago. The orchard generates a monthly profit of Kshs 40,000. Florah’s customers are residents of Koyoin–Kipsaraman, Nakuru, and Nairobi. A community leader introduced her to KADET. 

 Florah has taken out a loan of Kshs 60,000. Out of this loan, Kshs 5,000 will be used to purchase insecticides; Kshs 10,000 to purchase fertilizers; Kshs 15,000 to purchase mango and orange seedlings ; Kshs 20,000 to plant maize and bean seeds. and Kshs 10,000 to pay for labor.  

If this loan boosts her business, Florah will use the extra profit to plant more fruit, trees, maize, millet and buy  a dairy cow. She dreams and hopes to be a large-scale farmer. Florah describes herself as hard-working.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 120,000 to purchase more suits to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Paul Kiprotich

texts.en:
Paul Kiprotich R. is a thirty-six-year-old maize farmer in Kipsangui in Eldoret, Kenya. He is married to Peres R. and together they are blessed with four beautiful children.

Paul has been a farmer for four years now and he sells maize after harvest when he gets a monthly income of five thousand shillings. He also has a clinic in the same area.

Paul came to know about KADET through other KADET clients. This will be his first loan from KADET and he plans to use the loan to buy maize seedlings and fertilizer for his farm.

In the future, Paul wants to buy more land and become a large-scale farmer in Eldoret.

loans.use: To buy maize seedlings and fertilizer for his farm

loans.name: Chuluunhuu

texts.en:
Chuluunhuu D. is 43 years old and lives on her own in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She lives in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in a yard that belongs to her sister.

Chuluunhuu operates a shoe-trading business at Narantuul, the biggest outdoor market in Mongolia. She sells expensive, high-quality, designer shoes. She has been operating her business since 2000, and has steadily expanded her business since then. Her counter is in a good location with high levels of foot traffic. Since she founded her business, her living conditions have improved.

Chuluunhuu has successfully paid off her previous loan. She would like to expand her line of products in order to increase her profits. She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase spring and autumn shoes for her business.

Chuluunhuu is a responsible person who has good communication skills. She says, “I would really like to have my own plot of land. I will work hard to purchase some land by next year.”

loans.use: To purchase spring and autumn shoes for her business

loans.name: Joseph Maina

texts.en:
Joseph is 40 years old. He is married to Nancy, and they are blessed with one son.

Joseph has been running a transport business for the past two years. He also does mixed farming as his other source of income.

Joseph was introduced to KADET through an existing KADET client. He plans to expand both his transportation and farming businesses with the loan he has applied for.

Joseph would like to start rearing rabbits with the extra profit expected from his businesses. He describes himself as a hardworking business man.

loans.use: To expand his transportation and farming businesses

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 46 years old, married with 4 children. Her eldest child is 22 years old while the youngest child is 10 years old. Her children are doing well at school and this gives her joy as a mother. Her husband is an electrician and he also supports their home. She sells mouth watery Nigerian cooked foods to make a living in Benin City. She needs to expand her business in order to make more profits. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Mrs. Sokha Moen Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of nineteen people who are living in Chher Teal village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sokha M. is the village bank president, selected by all the members. Each member will use their loan for a different purpose. She is a vegetable seller in local market and her husband, Mr. Dorn Lorn, is a fisherman who earns some money from selling fishes. Her business is going well but she has a problem because her home is a long way from market. So to improve her business, Mrs. Sokha M. is applying for this loan to bU. a new motorbike to transport vegetables to resell, and with the rest of the loan she will bU. fish net. She is a mother of two children who are too yoU. to work or study.

loans.use: To buy a new motorbike to transport vegetables to the market to sell

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is 32 years old, married to Peter Mburu, and they have four children who are currently in school.

Ruth has been farming for the last seven years, growing crops and rearing livestock. She recently started rearing rabbits, a venture that has proved to be very profitable.

Ruth was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her fourth loan. She has repaid her previous loans successfully and on time. She is requesting a loan to build a new rabbit house, increase her livestock, and build a greenhouse where she will plant tomatoes and onions.

Ruth hopes to use the profit from her loan to develop her rabbit-rearing business and become a big supplier of rabbit meat in the local market.

loans.use: To build a new rabbit house, increase her livestock, and build a greenhouse to plant tomatoes and onions

loans.name: Gleen

texts.en: Mrs. Gleen R. is from Tambulig, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 34 years old and is married with four children. Gleen manages her business, which is sari-sari (variety) store, and her husband is a farmer. From her business she earns approximately PHP 5,000 a month. Her husband is also supporting their daily basic needs. Her main source of income, however, comes from her piggery. Gleen is a PDP-LP (Paglaum Development Program for Landless People) member. She joined PMPC to gain access to financial support and to engage in other business activities. She has successfully repaid her previous loan of PHP 5,000 from PMPC. This previous loan was for the expansion of her business. Now, Gleen has a new loan of PHP 10,000 from PMPC and the purpose of this loan is as additional capital of her sari-sari store. She is planning to purchase other kinds of goods from which she can earn more profit. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary is a LAPO client with good repayment record. She is 33 years old, married with 4 children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their home. Her children are excelling in school. She sells pineapples at retail prices to make a living. She is very happy to expand the size of her business in order to make more profits. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more pineapples to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more pineapples to sell

loans.name: Mercuria

texts.en:
Mercuria R., 53, is making sure that her family has enough provision for their daily needs. Married to Generoso R., a welder, the couple is blessed with four children. Mercuria makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her welding shop, together with her husband, for quite some time now.
Mercuria has been a regular member of Kiva partner, Center for Community Transformation (CCT), for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Her good repayment performance with her previous loans means she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her welding business.
To ensure the success of her business, Mercuria would like to apply for a loan of 30,000 PHP. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying equipment and welding materials. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can buy her own house and lot.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy equipment and welding materials

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel M. is a hardworking businessman of 29. He is married with one child. He owns a retail shop for motorcycle spare parts. He is a mechanic at the same time, doing repairs on the motorcycles of his customers.

He is using the loan to purchase business items, that is to say, quality spare parts to expand his business. His aspirations are to expand his business and build his own shop.

loans.use: To purchase quality spare parts to expand his business

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is 26 years old, married to Peter Baiya, and has one child. For the last two years, she has run a retail shop where she sells household goods in small quantities in Naivasha town.
Nancy was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to buy a deep freezer to put in her shop so that she can start selling milk and milk products. Nancy plans to grow her retail business as it has proved to have a good return on investment.

loans.use: To buy a deep freezer for her shop to start selling milk

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 38 years old, married to Patrick Yator, and they have three children. For the last two years, Grace has run a business raising livestock. She buys and rears different types of animals and sells them later at a profit.
Grace was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to buy two calves and sell them later at a profit. In the future, Grace plans to start dairy farming as she already has experience dealing with animals and can supply milk to the local market.

loans.use: To buy two calves for future resale

loans.name: Munhtuya

texts.en:
Munhtuya S., 40, lives with her husband and their 20-year-old son in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She runs a grocery store and movie rental service. She has been operating her store since 2003, when Munhtuya and her family built the store on their plot of land. Over the past seven years, she has successfully expanded her original grocery business, while also starting a movie rental service for extra income. Between 1996 and 2003, Munhtuya operated a vegetable trading business at the Huchir Shonhor market.
Munhtuya is a very hardworking person who has a great business mind. She has gained significant experience in her years as a trader. Munhtuya is focused on the future and says, “My goal is to expand my grocery store into a general store. In addition, I have been planning to build a workplace near the grocery store to rent out to other businesses.” She is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT loan to expand her grocery store and purchase inventory for her business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Demin Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Demin sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans  et  4 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames à KAMALEN SIRAKORO un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso pour satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Le prêt précédent s’est  bien  dénoué. 
Les membres du groupe font la vente de  poissons fumés (tels Sali K.),  de gingembre et  de fruits et légumes.       
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, Sali K. compte acheter,  50kg de poissons fumés . Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et revend au marché  de Kamalen Sirakoro  et à domicile, au comptant à une clientèle composée de femmes.
 Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 25.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elles comptent avoir plus de capitaux pour devenir grossiste afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
The members of group Demin are basically married women having an average age of 35 years old and 4 children. They live mostly in monogamous families at KAMALEN SIRAKORO, one of the villages of the Sikasso district, third administrative region of Mali. They are on their third loan with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution inorder to meet the needs of their clients. The preceding loan is repaid. Members of the group sell smoked fish (like Sali K.), ginger, fruits and vegetables. With their new loan, Sali K. intend to buy 50 kg of smoked fish. She gets her supplies in the big market of Sikasso town, retails at the Kamalen Sirakoro market and at home for cash to customers made up of women. She envisions to make a monthly profit of 25.500FCFA of which part will be used for saving and the needs of the family, and the other part will be invested in the business. They intend to have more capital in order to become wholesalers to better meet the needs of their clientele.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of smoked fish

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn is 49 years old, a widow with 3 children. She sells groceries and drinks at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to own a super market in the future. She   wants to expand her business in order to make more profits to cater for her children. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Hotensiah

texts.en:
Hotensiah is 42 years old, married to Simon Ngugi, and has five children who go to school. She has a business selling clothes as she walks around Naivasha town.
Hotensiah was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the loan to buy more clothes to sell. In the future, Hotensiah plans to sell her clothes from a permanent shop.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Eden

texts.en:
Since the early years of their marriage, Eden M. and her husband have cultivated land for rice farming. Their income from this activity is the source for meeting Eden’s family's needs. This livelihood has supported the education of her only child (who is now 30 years old) in college until his graduation from a two-year course in agriculture. While he is not yet employed, he has been a great help to his parents in their rice-farming business.
Compared to the average expenses that a farmer should spend on rice farming, it is now a very expensive occupation because the prices of farm inputs and equipment rentals are higher than before. Eden and her husband, just like all those who had no opportunity to access a loan with low interest, would take a loan from money lenders who charge huge amounts of interest. Therefore, after harvesting and selling the rice, their profit would be very small and not even enough to support their family's basic needs.
As a consequence, Eden and her husband agreed to obtain loans from Kiva partner, ASHI, since becoming a member in 2007. Eventually, life has become easier and enjoyable for her and her family, although their business is still unstable and has not grown so well. Eden is hoping that with the loan she is requesting now, her business would improve a bit further.

loans.use: To purchase rice seedlings, fertlizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Thomas

texts.en:
Thomas is 41 years old, married to Janeffer Sote, and they have six children. He has been rearing livestock to sell in Naivasha town for the last 15 years.
Thomas was introduced to Kiva partner, KADET, by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to buy more sheep, which he will sell later at a profit. With the help of his loan, Thomas hopes to increase his livestock, which will help to increase his income.

loans.use: To buy sheep for future resale

loans.name: Tinh

texts.en: Tinh T. N. is 34 years old and married with two young children. She is a farmer, and also makes tofu to sell in her village. She has been in this business for many years. Tinh T. N. has a monthly income of about 4,000,000 VND. She has participated in Kiva partner, SEDA, since 2003 and repaid her loans punctually. For this loan, she wants to borrow 8,066,000 VND to buy beans to make tofu.

loans.use: To buy beans to make tofu

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en:
Margarita L., 37, is married to Mario L. and they are blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. Margarita makes sure that her family has enough provision for their daily needs. She has been managing her own rug-making shop for quite some time now.
Margarita has been a regular member of Kiva partner, Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Her good repayment performance with her previous loans means she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her rug business.
To ensure the success of her business, Margarita would like to apply for a loan of 12,000 PHP. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying raw materials needed to continue rug production. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can cater to more customers and have more patrons.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for rug production

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is 37 years old, married with 6 children. Her husband also works to support their home. Her children attend school and this gives her joy. She sells groceries and drinks at retail prices to her customers. She is very determined to increase the size of her business in order to make more profits. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Jiguisèmè Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Jiguisèmè sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans et  3 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames à KAMALEN SIRAKORO un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur troisième  prêt solidaire. Les prêts précédents se sont bien dénoués. 
Les membres de son groupe  font la vente d’ignames, de fruits, de friperie et  de condiments alimentaires. 
 Avec leur nouveau prêt, MARIAM T. compte acheter, 2 balles de friperie. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Sikasso ville. Elle revend au marché de Kamalen Sirakoro, dans les foires des villages avoisinants  Kamalen Sirakoro et à domicile, au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle compte avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et  pouvoir aménager un point de vente.
texts.en:
The members of the Jiguisèmè group are married women, on average 30 years old with three children. Mostly they live in monogamous families in Kamalen Sirakoro, a village in the commune of Sikasso in Mali's 3rd administrative region. They work with Soro Yiriwaso, a microfinance institution, to meet their customers' needs, and are currently repaying their third loan. They sell yams, fruit, used clothing and condiments. With their new loan Mariam T. plans on buying two bales of used clothing from the big market in Sikasso city for resale in the market in Kamalen Sirakoro, in neighboring villages, and from home, for cash and on credit to both men and women customers. She hopes for an average monthly income of 17,500 FCFA, some to be saved, some for her family's needs, and some to be invested in her business. With this increased capital, she hopes better to serve her customers and to be able to operate from a single location.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy used clothing

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is a mechanic in Naivasha town. He is 33 years old, married to Mary Achieng, and they have five children. He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his 2nd loan. He has repaid his previous loan successfully and on time. Peter plans to use his new loan to buy new auto repair tools so he can become a bigger player in the mechanics industry in Naviasha town.

loans.use: To buy a buffing machine and a welding machine.

loans.name: Mr. Vai Sam Village Bank Group

texts.en:
In Chheu Teal village, in Kandall province, there are fourteen people who are taking out a village bank loan. Mr. Vai S. is the village bank president, selected by all the members. Each will use their portion of the loan for a different purpose. He and his wife, Mrs. Sok Lorn K., are farmers who own a  one-hectare plot of land to grow rice and vegetables to sell to support their family living.

Their problem is that their field is ready for farming, but they did not have enough money. So to improve production, Mr. Vai S. is requesting a loan to do farming. He is a father of seven children: two are farmers, four are attending a local public school, and the last is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To do farming

loans.name: George

texts.en: George has been a mechanic in Naivasha town for the last 10 years. He is 25 years old and married to Susan O.. He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the cash from this loan to buy a buffing machine. George hopes to open his own auto repair garage one day.

loans.use: To buy a buffing machine

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily D. is from the town of Banga. She is 45 years old and married with four school-aged children. Emily has a business planting and harvesting rice. She has been engaged in her business for over 24 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Emily joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Emily from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family. 

About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly in recent years. Based in Bohol, it has numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Vanndy

texts.en: Mrs. Vanndy K. is 48 years old and a villager who lives in Prey Ta Pong village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Sengly Horm, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice. Aside from farming, Mrs. Vanndy K. is electric supply seller and her husband is a construction worker. In order to help her husband get to his work place, Mrs. Vanndy K. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorcycle to support her husband's transportation. This couple has two children who are both students in the local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul has been a farmer for five years. He is 49 years old, married to Joyce Wachuka, and they have four children. He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his 3rd loan. He repaid the previous two loans successfully and on time. He plans to use this loan to buy fertilizer and cultivate his land for planting. Paul hopes to become a large-scale vegetable grower and be able to supply his produce to big companies and supermarkets in bulk.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and cultivate his land for planting

loans.name: Ijoma

texts.en: Ijoma is 34 years old, married with 4 children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy as a mother. She sells electrical materials at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger in the future. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more electrical materials to sell.  She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more electrical materials to sell

loans.name: Kotognogontala Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Kotognogontala sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans,  3 enfants et  vivant la plupart dans des familles monogames à KAMALEN SIRAKORO un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur troisième  prêt. Les  prêts passés ont été bien remboursés. 
Les membres du groupe font la vente  de condiments alimentaires,  de savons,  de médicaments traditionnels,  des friandises  et  des poissons fumés.
 Avec son nouveau prêt, Minata D. qui fait les condiments alimentaires compte acheter, 4 colis  de condiments (tomates + oignons + poivres + choux + gombo +sel + huile + pâte d’arachide etc.). Elle s’approvisionne au marché de Sikasso ville et dans les villages avoisinants. Elle revend au marché de KAMALEN SIRAKORO  et à domicile, au comptant et souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes.
 Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 32.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Elle compte avoir plus de capitaux pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et  aménager son point de vente.
texts.en:
The members of the Kotognogontala group are all married women and are on average 30 years old with three children. Most live in monogamous families in KAMALEN SIRAKORO, one of the villages in the commune of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to satisfy their customers’ needs and are requesting a third group loan. All past loans have been repaid in full. Group members sell food condiments, soap, traditional medications, sweets and smoked fish. With her new loan Minata D. (who prepares food condiments) will buy 4 packages of condiments (tomatoes, onions, peppers, cabbage, gombos, salt, oil, peanut paste, etc.). She gets her supplies from the market in Sikasso and from neighbouring villages. She resells at the KAMALEN SIRAKORO market and through home delivery, for cash and often for credit, to women customers. She is hoping to attain an average monthly income of 32,500 FCFA of which part will be put into savings and used for family expenses, while the remainder will be reinvested in the commercial activities. She is hoping to accumulate more capital to better satisfy her customers and to fix up her stall.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments

loans.name: David

texts.en: David K. is 27 years old and married to Mary Muthoni. They have one beautiful child called Favour. David lives in Bahati in Eldoret where owns a shop selling mobile phone accessories. He has been in this business for six years and makes thirty thousand shillings per month. David was introduced to KADET by his friend who is also a client. This will be his fourth loan with KADET and he plans to use it to buy more mobile phone accessories for resale. His dream is to open more shops so that he can make more income and improve his family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more phone accessories for his shop

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie B., 45, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Elesio, a steel man, they are blessed with four children in their marriage. Melanie makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life, managing her own buy-and-sell business which includes bags, clothes and home amenities.

A regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now, Melanie regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative to expand and improve her businesses.

To ensure the continued success of her business, Melanie would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan to buy more quantities of products needed to replenish and maintain the operation of her businesses. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide a happy and comfortable life for her family.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro finance loans.

loans.use: To purchase additional materials for the business

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: K. Paul is thirty-five years old and married with five children. He owns a clinic (Hope Medical Centre) on Zirridamu Street, in Kalisizo sub-county, Kyotera county, Rakai district. His clinic provides admission for patients. He is using the loan to purchase clinical equipment and machines. He is a very hardworking businessman whose future aspirations are to expand the clinic and build a better and more convenient place for patients. He also wants to make sure all his children are educated.

loans.use: To purchase clinical equipment and machines

loans.name: Leslie

texts.en:
Leslie M. is from the town of Banga. She is 18 years old. Leslie is single. To make a living, Leslie operates a family member's agricultural business raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice and corn to sell. Leslie has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Leslie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leslie is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Leslie from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support her family.

About CEVI:
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly in recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but, additionally, savings, insurance, and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Heang

texts.en: Mrs. Heang Y. is 55 years old and she lives in Kor village in Takeo province. Mrs. Heang Y. and her husband, Mr. No Charb, are farmers who own a plot of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Heang Y. is now requesting a loan to buy a motorcycle for transportation. This couple has five children: one is on the  staff of a private company, two are construction workers, one owns a general store, and the youngest is a student in a local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: David Kipkemoi

texts.en:
David Kipkemoi K. is 26 years old, married, and the father of one beautiful child named Chelagat, who is one and a half years old. He is a farmer in Sinonin in Eldoret. He plants maize and sells the produce after the harvest. He has been in this business for the last five years and earns a profit of three thousand shillings monthly.

He first learned about KADET through another KADET client. With the loan, David is planning to buy fertilizer and maize seedlings and use the rest of the loan for plowing his land to plant the maize. His dream is to buy a bigger plot of land to expand his farming business.

loans.use: To buy farm necessities such as fertilizer, maize seedlings, and plowing supplies

loans.name: Saniya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Saniya sont essentiellement des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans et en moyenne  5 enfants. Elles  vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à KAMALEN SIRAKORO un des villages de la commune de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali.
