Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur troisième  prêt. Les prêts  passés ont été bien remboursés. Le  groupe font  le commerce d’articles divers tels la vente  du charbon de bois,  des fruits et légumes  et de la  friperie.
Avec leur nouveau prêt, Nantenin D. qui la présidente du groupe et qui excelle dans l’achat et la vente de charbon de bois, compte acheter environ une soixantaine de sacs de charbon de bois auprès des producteurs. Et pour cela  elle s’approvisionne dans les villages avoisinants  Kamalen Sirakoro. Elle  revend aux marchés de Médine, du centre ville  et à domicile, au comptant et  souvent à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
 Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 27.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour l’épargne et les besoins de la famille, l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Saniya group are for the most part married women and are on average 42 years old with five children. Most live in polygamous families in KAMALEN SIRAKORO, one of the villages in the commune of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). They collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI to satisfy their customers’ needs and are requesting a third group loan. All past loans have been repaid in full. Group members retail various products such as charcoal, fruit and vegetables, and used clothing. With the new loan Nantenin D. (who is the group president and excels in trading charcoal) wishes to buy about 60 bags of charcoal from the producers. For her supplies she goes to villages in the vicinity of Kamalen Sirakoro. She resells in the Medina market in the centre of town, and through home delivery, for cash and often for credit, to both men and women customers. She is hoping to attain an average monthly income of 27,500 FCFA of which part will be put into savings and used for family expenses, while the remainder will be reinvested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy charcoal

loans.name: Kudirat

texts.en:
Kudirat sells groceries and has been in this trade for many years now. She is requesting for a loan of NGN170, 000 to purchase more groceries to sell, this she said will reduce cost prize, transportation to market and increase her profit. Also enable her serve costumers better and improve on her care for the family.
Kudirat is 64 years old, widow and has three children. The family lives in Lagos state. Kudirat says thank you to all lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Otuma Ole

texts.en:
Otuma Ole N. is 25 years old. He is married to Kisianani N. and is the father of two children.

Otuma is a farmer, and he has been farming for the last five years. His farm is in a productive area that has proved to be good for wheat farming.

He learned about KADET through a marketing campaign done by KADET staff members in his area of residence. This will be his second loan, which he is planning to use to prepare six acres for wheat planting. He hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire more land for farming, to increase his wheat production.

His hope and dream is to become a large-scale farmer and buy a bigger piece of land. Otuma describes himself as a young and energetic man.

loans.use: To prepare six acres for wheat planting

loans.name: Chhom

texts.en: Mrs. Chhom O. is 51 years old and she is a villager who lives in Andoung Samretth village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Aon Tous, are farmers who own 2.50 hectares of land to cultivate rice. Aside from being farmers, Mrs. Chhom O. is Khmer noodle seller and her husband is fisherman. With these businesses they can earn a small income to support their family. For the farm, Mrs. Chhom O. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide and rice seed to support her farming crop and the rest of the loan she wants use to buy piglets and pig food for pig breeding. This couple has two children who all are staff workers in a private company. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: For fertilizer, pesticide, seed, piglets, and pig food

loans.name: Mrs. Choeun Uk Village Bank Group

texts.en: Sixteen people in Chheu Teal village in Kandal province are taking out a village bank loan. They will each use their portion of the loan in different ways to  improve their businesses in the future. Mrs. Choeun U. is the village bank president who has been selected by all the members. She is a farmer who rents a small piece of land to grow rice and vegetables to sell to support her family. Her field is ready for farming; Mrs. Choeun U. is asking for a loan to improve production. Her husband, Mr. Mab Bul, is a cow middleman. Mrs. Choeun U. is a mother of a child who is seven years old.

loans.use: To do farming

loans.name: Beatrice Raino

texts.en:
Beatrice Raino L. is 48 years old. She is married to Koileken L. and is the mother of three children who go to school. 

She is a farmer who has been farming on her own land for the last ten years.

She learnt about KADET through an awareness campaign done by KADET staff members in her town. This will be her second loan. She will use the loan to prepare her land and to plant wheat. With the remainder of the loan, she will start rearing sheep. With the profits she hopes to earn, she intends to plant wheat in a larger plot of land and to buy more sheep.

Her dream for the future is to be able to buy a large enough plot of land to start commercial farming. Beatrice believes she is hardworking and that all she needs are the resources to attain her goals.

loans.use: To plow her land, plant wheat, and buy sheep

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena J., age 39, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Ausenio, a vegetable vendor, and their marriage is blessed with 2 children. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing a variety store while helping in her husband’s vegetable business.

Elena has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and consistently pays her weekly dues. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow from CCT’s Cooperative quite a few times. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business. She will use the loan funds to buy more of the products that she needs to replenish and maintain operations of her businesses.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide a happy and comfortable life for her family.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional stock to add to her product inventory

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Âgée de 37 ans, Fatoumata Sidibé est mariée et mère 5 enfants. Elle réside avec son époux et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Bougoula Ville, le centre ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Fatoumata Sidibé, après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée depuis plus de 10 ans à l’activité d’achat et vente d’habillements (pagnes Wax, tissus brodés) de chaussures,  des savons liquides etc qu’elle achète à Bobo Dioulasso (république de Burkina Faso). Elle mène son activité à son domicile et de façon ambulante dans la ville de Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a maintenant cinq  ans. Après plusieurs prêts solidaires dans un association des femmes de son quartier, elle est actuellement  à son huitième prêt individuel et  tous ses prêts précédents ont été tous correctement remboursés.
 Elle compte acheter avec ce  nouveau prêt, 15 pièces de pagne Wax, 5 complets de tissus brodés et 20 paires de chaussures différentes. Ses marchandises sont vendues en détail, de façon ambulante, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 250 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Fatoumata Sidibé is 37 years old, married and the mother of five children. She lives with her husband and children in a large traditional extended household in Bougoula Ville, in the centre of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). After a number of unsuccessful ventures, Mrs. Fatoumata Sidibé began over ten years ago to trade in clothing: pagnes Wax (colourful West African clothing fabric), embroidered fabrics, shoewear, liquid soap, all of which she purchases in Bobo Dioulasso (in the Republic of Burkina Faso). She conducts her business from her home and as an itinerant vendor throughout Sikasso, where she is much in demand due to the quality of her products. To satisfy an increasing customer base, she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI some five years ago. Following several group loans as part of a group of neighbourhood women, she is now requesting an 8th individual loan, having reimbursed in full all preceding loans. She intends to buy 15 pagnes wax, 5 complete sets of embroidered clothes and 20 pairs of shoes of different styles. She sells her merchandise as an itinerant retailer, for cash or credit, to mainly women customers. She hopes to attain a monthly profit of 250,000 FCFA which will be used to increase her working capital, contribute towards family expenses and paying back her loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various items

loans.name: Nkwenye Ole

texts.en:
Nkwenye Ole K. is 32 years old. He is married to Napilosh K. and is the father of children who go to school. Nkwenye is a farmer. He has been farming his own land for the last five years.
  
He learned about KADET from a colleague who was a registered KADET client in his neighborhood. This will be his second loan. He is planning to spend 35,000 KES to prepare his land for wheat farming and the other 30,000 KES to buy some sheep to fatten and sell later. With the profits he hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, he plans to reinvest in the farm and plant more acres of wheat.

His hope and dream is to become a large-scale farmer both in wheat farming and sheep rearing.

loans.use: To prepare the land for wheat farming and to buy sheep to raise and sell

loans.name: Soeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Soeurn S. is 47 years old and lives in Andoung Samretth village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns one and a half hectares of land to cultivate rice. Aside from farming, she also breeds ducks for their eggs. Mrs. Soeurn S. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, rice seed, pesticide, and duck food. as well as to hire a farm laborer. She is a widow with three children -- one is a duck breeder who helps support the business and the other two are students.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, rice seed, pesticide, and duck food, and to hire a farm laborer.

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida G., age 44, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Rico, a driver, and their marriage is blessed with 4 children. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has primarily been managing her rug-making business.

Aida has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow from CCT’s Cooperative 11 times.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 17,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business. She will use the loan funds to buy more products that are needed to replenish and maintain the operations of her businesses.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide a happy and comfortable life for her family.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for rug-making

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth V. is from the town of Banga. She is 55 years old. Ruth is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Ruth plants, harvests, and sells rice. Ruth has been engaged in her business for over 20 years.

In 2010, Ruth joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ruth is requesting a loan of 6000 PHP to purchase fertilizer, such as manure and seeds. This will be Ruth's first loanfrom CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure and seeds

loans.name: Ogboifun

texts.en: Ogboifun O. is 45 years old, married with 6 children. She sells fire woods at retail prices to her customers. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger in the future. She is determined to expand in her business. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more fire woods to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fire woods to sell

loans.name: Nderi Ole

texts.en:
Nderi Ole S. is 33 years old. He is married to Margaret S. and is the father of three children.

Nderi has been a farmer for the past five years. His farm is in a productive area which has proven to be good for wheat farming.

He learned about KADET through a marketing campaign done by the KADET staff in his neighborhood. This will be his second loan. He is planning to prepare thirteen acres to plant wheat, which normally does well in his area due to good climatic conditions. He hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire more land for farming to increase his wheat production.

His hope and dream is to become a large-scale farmer and buy a bigger piece of land.

loans.use: To prepare thirteen acres for wheat planting

loans.name: Aïssata

texts.fr:
Née le 10 Janvier 1981 à Sikasso, Aïssata Kouyaté est marée et mère 3 enfants. Elle réside avec son époux et leurs enfants à Hamdallaye Extension, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Aïssata Kouyaté, après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à l’activité d’achat et  de vente d’habillements (pagnes Wax, de tissus brodés) de chaussures  etc. Elle mène son activité à son domicile et au marché de Hamdallaye où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a maintenant deux ans. Après 4 prêts solidaires dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son premier prêt individuel. Ses prêts solidaires précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 10 pièces de pagne Wax, 8 complets de tissus brodés. Elle achète ses marchandises à Bobo Dioulasso (république de Burkina Faso) avant de les revendre en détail, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée essentiellement des femmes..
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 95 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born 10 January 1981 in Sikasso, Aïssata Kouyaté is married and the mother of three children. She lives with her husband and children in Hamdallaye Extension, one of the populous boroughs in Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After a number of unsuccessful ventures, Mrs. Aïssata Kouyaté began to trade in clothing: pagnes Wax (colourful West African clothing fabric), embroidered fabrics, shoewear, etc. She conducts her business from her home and at the Hamdallaye market, where she is much in demand due to the quality of her products. To satisfy an increasing customer base, she decided two years ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI. Following four group loans as part of a group of neighbourhood women, she is now requesting her first individual loan. Her preceding group loans were all correctly reimbursed. With her loan she intends to buy 10 pagnes wax, and 8 complete sets of embroidered clothes. She gets her merchandise from Bobo Dioulasso (in the Republic of Burkina Faso) before retailing it for cash or credit, to mainly women customers. She hopes to attain a monthly profit of 95,000 FCFA which will be used to increase her working capital, contribute towards family expenses and paying back her loan.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy plothing

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma R., 49, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. She is married to Renato, a retailer, and they are blessed with 4 children. She helps her husband earn income so that their family can have a better life.  She has been helping her husband in the family’s buy-and-sell business. They trade items such as clothes and home products like chairs, linoleums and drawers.

Norma has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow seven times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she has used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of additional capital to buy products needed to replenish stock and maintain operation of her expanding business.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide a happy and comfortable life for her family.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy stock

loans.name: Sinuon

texts.en: Mrs. Sinuon R. is 38 years old and lives in Srae Boeng village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns one and a half hectares of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Sinuon R. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and to pay for a water machine. Aside from farming she also sells cakes in the local village which also earns a small income to support her family. Mrs. Sinuon R. is a widow with two children who are both students in the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides and to pay for water machine.

loans.name: Sinoyia Ole

texts.en:
Sinoyia Ole N. is 42 years old. He is married to Nauruai N. and he is the father of two children. 

Sinoyia is a farmer and has been farming his land for the past ten years.
  
He learnt about KADET from a member of a group that is registered with KADET. This will be his second loan. He is planning to prepare fifteen acres for wheat planting which normally does well in his area due to good climatic conditions. With the profits, he plans to re-invest in his farm and plant more acres of wheat.

His hope and dream is to become a large scale farmer and to be able to plant one hundred acres of wheat

loans.use: to prepare fifteen acres for wheat planting

loans.name: Omolade

texts.en:
Omolade has a shop where she sells drinks and juice for a living in Lagos state, Nigeria. She buys in bulk and sells in retail.  She has been in this business since 2008.
Omolade is 38 years old, married and has two children, with her business she care for her aged parents who are living with her and also support her husband in paying off the family expense.
Omolade is requesting for a loan of NGN70, 000 to purchase more drinks and juice to sell. She says thank you and promise to repay promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and juice to sell

loans.name: Boudrosse Al Maou

texts.fr:
Né le 02 Septembre 1983 à Kita (région de Kayes), Monsieur Boudrosse Al Maou Keïta  est célibataire sans enfant résidant à Hamdallaye Extension, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
   Monsieur Keïta, après l’obtention du certificat d’aptitude professionnelle en bâtiment (CAP BÂTIMENT), s’est initié à la fabrique des savons qu’il a appris  à Bamako en marge de ses études il y a environ six ans. Il mène son activité  à son domicile avant de les revendre à Koutiala et à San où il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a quelque mois. Il est à son premier prêt individuel et compte l’utiliser pour acheter, 2 futs d’huile de coco, 2 sacs de soude caustique, 1 carton de parfum, etc.
   Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 120 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born 2 September 1983 in Kita (in the Kayes region), Mr. Boudrosse Al Maou Keïta is unmarried with no children, and resides in Hamdallaye Extension, one of the populous boroughs in Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mr. Keïta obtained a professional certification in building construction (CAP Bâtiment), but six years ago began manufacturing soap, which he had learned to do in Bamako during his studies. He conducts his business at his home before selling his products in Koutiala and in San, where he is much in demand due to the quality of his products. To satisfy an ever-increasing customer base, he decided a few months ago to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI. He is now requesting his first individual loan to buy two barrels of coconut oil, two bags of lye, one carton of perfume, etc. With this loan he hopes to attain a monthly profit of 120,000 FCFA, which will be used to deal with daily expenses, pay back his loan, and invest the remainder in his commercial activity.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ingredients to make soap

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
41-year-old Shirley S. is from the town of Banga. She is married and has 2 school-aged children. She owns & operates a livestock business, raising ducks to produce eggs which she sells. She also owns a small sari-sari (variety) store situated at her house. Shirley has been engaged in her business for over 9 years.

In 2010, Shirley joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Shirley is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Shirley from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to financially support her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Mansour

texts.fr: Monsieur Mansour H., divorcé et père de 2 enfants, est âgé de 50 ans. Il est dans le métier de chauffeur de taxi, il y'a 25 ans. C'est en 2007 qu'il a acquis un taxi avec un prêt accordé par U-IMCEC Thiès. Cependant, Monsieur Mansour H. souhaitait réfectionner son taxi. Ainsi il sollicite un prêt de 200 000 FCFA qu'il va compléter avec ses économies épargnées afin de retaper son taxi.
texts.en:
Mr. Mansour H., aged 50, is a divorced father of two children. He has been working in the trade of taxi driving for 25 years. In 2007, he acquired a taxi with a loan granted by U-IMCEC Thiès. However, he wishes to refurbish his taxi. He is therefore requesting a loan of 200,000 francs CFA that he will round out with his own savings in order to fix up his taxi.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Refurbishing his taxi

loans.name: Ra

texts.en: Mrs. Ra T. is 37 years old and she lives in Rung B village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Sophal Resch, are farmers who own three hectares of land to cultivate rice. Mrs. Ra T. is asking for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer, and pesticide, and to hire a farm laborer. The couple has four children; one is laborer in Thai country while the other three are students in the local school. (Her husband is in the picture with her.)

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer, and pesticide and to hire a farm laborer

loans.name: Vergie

texts.en:
Vergie S., 26, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. She is married to Joselito, a garbage collector, and they are blessed with 3 children. She helps her husband earn income so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own gasoline vending and rug-making business.

Vergie has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow seven times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 8,000 loan. This amount will be used as additional capital to buy stock and maintain operation of her expanding business.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide a happy and comfortable life for her family.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy stock of gasoline and diesel

loans.name: John  Yator

texts.en:
John is a 28-year-old, single man. He is a maize farmer who began farming three years ago. John’s farm is near the road, which makes it easily accessible, and on fertile land. His clients are residents of Kaptallam in Kabernet. The crop gives him a monthly profit of Kshs 1,200. He also keeps livestock from which he gets additional income.

He has borrowed a loan of Kshs 10,000 from KADET. A friend who is a KADET client introduced him to this organization. This is the first financial institution from which John has ever borrowed a loan. He will use this loan to purchase maize seeds and other farm inputs. 
 
If this loan boosts his business he will use the extra profit to improve his living standard. He dreams and hopes to be a famous farmer within his community. He aims to achieve this by having a big farm. John describes himself as a staunch Christian who is humble, hardworking, and ready to face any challenge in order to be successful.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and other farm inputs

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma V. is from the town of Banga. She is 38 years old. Vilma is married and has 2 school-aged children. Vilma owns & operates a crop growing business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Vilma has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Vilma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Vilma is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Vilma from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to supplement her family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Chuchie

texts.en:
Chuchie S., 51, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. She is married to Freddie, a driver, and they are blessed with 3 children. She helps her husband earn income so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store.

Chuchie has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow five times in CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as additional capital to buy stock and maintain operation of her business.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide a happy and comfortable life for her family.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to provide additional working capital

loans.name: Kanha

texts.en: Mrs. Kanha C. is a 27 year old married woman.  She lives in Lieb village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Vuthea San, are farmers who own 4 hectares of land on which they cultivate rice. Mrs. Kanha C. decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline to support her farming operation. In addition to being a farmer, Mr. Vuthea San is a construction worker and also owns an agri machine to transport soil for selling. This couple has three children; two are attending the local school, while the youngest one is too young to study or work. The couple are pictured together.

loans.use: To buy rice seed, fertilizer, pesticide and gasoline

loans.name: Diakalia

texts.fr:
Monsieur Diakalia Traoré est né le 26 Janvier 1971 à Sikasso, marié et père de quatre enfants. Il réside avec son épouse et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie au quartier de Bougoula Ville, le centre ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Traoré  s’est initié à ce métier de menuiserie bois dès son jeune âge auprès de son père  qui était un maître d'œuvres très connu et très sollicité par la population Sikassoise. 
Avec sa grande expérience dans le domaine, Monsieur Diakalia reçoit beaucoup de commandes, mais les moyens dont il dispose sont insuffisants pour mieux satisfaire tous ces besoins qui ne cesse d’augmenter, il décida alors de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus de deux ans avec laquelle il est à son troisième prêt individuel. Ainsi il sollicite ce  troisième  prêt pour augmenter son fonds de roulement afin de mieux relancer son activité pour pouvoir répondre aux attentes de ses clients qui ne cesse d’augmenter. Ainsi avec ce troisième prêt, il compte acheter un chargement et demi de camion “10 tonnes”  en Chevrons et planches et  un demi chargement de contre plaqués.  
 Il achète ses bois dans les localités environnantes (Tinkrela, Denderso, Lobougoula, etc.) avant de les scier et les amener à Sikasso pour en faire des meubles, bancs, tables-bancs, bureau, chaises afin de les revendre. 
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 275 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Diakalia Traoré was born on January 26, 1971 in Sikasso. He is married and the father of four children. He resides with his wife and their children in a large traditional extended family in the Bougoula Ville district, in downtown Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). He was introduced to this wood-working trade of his by his father, who used to be a master builder and well-known by the people of Sikasso. With a great deal of experience in this domain, he receives many orders. But since he can't afford to satisfy all of the ever-growing demand, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso over two year ago and is now on his third individual loan. He is requesting this third loan for increasing his working capital in order to reinvigorate his business and to respond to customer expectations, which are ever-growing. Thus, with this third loan, Diakalia plans on buying 1½ truck loads (ten-tonne size) of rafters and boards and a half load of plywood sheets. He purchases his lumber in the surrounding towns (Tinkrela, Denderso, Lobougoula, etc.), cuts them up, and takes them to Sikasso to make furniture: benches, bench-tables, desks, and chairs in order to sell them. Diakalia envisions using this loan to make a monthly profit of 275,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to help with family expenses, to pay the loan interest, and to reinvest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying lumber

loans.name: Kaitet Ole

texts.en:
Kaitet Ole N. is 47 years old, married to Kinyeketa N., and the father of three children. 

Kaitet is a farmer and  has been farming his land for the last seven years.
  
He learnt about KADET from a member of a group within his locality that is registered with KADET. This will be his second loan. He is planning to prepare fifteen acres of land for wheat planting which normally does well in his area due to good climatic conditions. With the profits, he plans to re-invest in the farm and plant more acres of wheat.

His hope and dream is to become a large scale farmer and to be able to buy his own farm machinery.

loans.use: to prepare fifteen acres for wheat planting

loans.name: Nataiyuang Enole

texts.en:
Nataiyuang Enole P. is 28 years old. She is married to Rereu Ole P. and is the mother of three children who go to school.

Nataiyuang is a farmer and has been farming her land for the past ten years.

She learnt about KADET from other women in a group already registered with KADET in her area of residence. This will be her second loan which she is planning to use to prepare land for maize planting. Maize has been doing well in her area due to good climatic conditions. She hopes to use the profits to expand her farming activity from small scale to commercial farming.

Nataiyuang's dream is do large scale farming and attain financial independence. She is a hard working woman who is determined to achieve her set goals

loans.use: to prepare land for maize planting

loans.name: Kim Lieng

texts.en: Mrs. Kim Lieng K. is 53 years old.  She lives in Prachreay village in Takeo province. She and her husband, Mr. Chhouk Sok, are farmers who own 2 hectares of land on which they cultivate rice. In addition to being a farmer, Mrs. Kim Lieng K. is also a grocery seller who earns a small income to support her family. In order to increase her income and improve her family’s living situation, she decided to ask for a loan to buy piglets and pig food for her new business. This couple has three children; two are students and one is a grocery seller who also supports the mother’s business. The couple are pictured together.

loans.use: To buy piglets and pig food

loans.name: Maïssata

texts.fr:
Maïssata S. est une veuve âgée de 56 ans et mère de 6 enfants qui réside chez son grand frère à Médine-Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
    Maïssata, après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée pendant 2 ans à la fabrication de savons traditionnels (savons noirs)  qu’elle a apprise auprès d’une amie. Elle mène son activité  à  son domicile où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus d’un an.
Dans l’objectif de mieux relancer son activité pour pouvoir répondre aux attentes de sa  clientèle, elle sollicite ainsi un deuxième prêt.
 Elle compte acheter avec ce deuxième prêt , 5 futs des déchets d’huile de coton (pattes noires), 2 futs d’huile de coton, 5 sacs de soude caustique, 1 paquet de parfum et 4 chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe. 
Elle achète ses matières premières sur place et à Bobo Dioulasso (république de Burkina Faso).
 Après fabrication des savons, elles les revend en détail à une clientèle composée généralement des femmes.
   Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce et contribuer aux dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
Maïssata S., aged 56, is a widow and the mother of six children who resides at her grandfather's place in Médine-Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having worked in many businesses without success, she was introduced two years ago to making traditional soaps (black soap), which she learned how to make from a friend. Working out of her home, she is much in demand for the quality of her products. To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, Maïssata decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso over a year ago. With the goal of reinvigorating business further, in order to respond to customer expectations, she is therefore requesting a second loan. She plans on using this second loan to buy five barrels of waste cotton oil (black paste), two drums of cotton oil, five sacks of caustic soda, a packet of perfume, and four cart loads of firewood. She purchases her ingredients locally and in Bobo Dioulasso (Republic of Burkina Faso). After making the soaps, she sells them retail to a customer base composed generally of women. With this loan, Maïssata envisions making a monthly profit of 150,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to increase her working capital and to help cover family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying raw materials for making soap

loans.name: Harison

texts.en:
Harison is a 23-year-old, single man. 

Harison is a farmer. He started his business 3 years ago and makes a profit of Kshs 7,000 per month. 

He has received a loan of Kshs 10,000 from KADET. He will use half of the loan to buy fertilizers and to cultivate his land. The other half will be used to buy hybrid maize and beans.

His business is in Kaptallam. His clients are students, employees, teachers and the community of Moi Teachers' Training College.

If this loan boosts his business, Harison will use the extra profit to improve the living standards of his family and to pay school fees for his brothers and sisters. He dreams and hopes to live above the poverty line. He describes himself as industrious and hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina B. believes that along with her supportive and loving husband and children, she can jump up through the wall of poverty and experience life in new dimensions. Through the proceeds of the business she has built up and has been growing (with the help of her husband), and with the help of the loans she has been receiving from ASHI since she became a member in 2002, her dream can come true. 

Now Gina is requesting a much larger loan to grow her hog-raising business. She wishes to purchase more piglets to raise for breeding and selling to people in her village or in the market. From the proceeds, she will create savings for her family’s education so they can graduate from college and have their own careers in the future.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for raising and breeding

loans.name: Abiola

texts.en:
Abiola is a trader, she sells and supply bottled and sachet drinking water for various ceremonies, she has been in business for over ten years and with this trade she supports her husband in providing for the needs of the family. Abiola is a faithful LAPO client, she goes to factory once in two weeks to get bottled and sachet water in large quantity at a discount. 

She is requesting for a loan of NGN70, 000 to purchase more drinking water to sell which will enable her meet customers’ demands while increasing her profit. 
Abiola is 44years old and has four children, she says thank you to Kiva lenders and promise to pay back her loan promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more drinking water to sell

loans.name: Ney

texts.en: Mrs. Ney T. is 36 years old and she lives in Sla village in Takeo province. She is a clothing seller who earns a small income to support her family. For this business, Mrs. Ney T. decided to ask for a loan to add her savings. This will help her to buy more clothes to enlarge her business. With this loan she hopes to increase her income to improve her family's living conditions. Her husband, Mr. Vy Tham, is a famer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. This couple has two children who are both students in the local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell

loans.name: Erustus Kiprop

texts.en:
Erustus is 28 years old and is married to Magdalene Chebet who is a business lady. They have one child, Kipruto Kiprop, who is 2 years old. Erustus is a commercial farmer. He started this venture 2 years ago and earns a profit of Kshs 2,000. Other sources give him a monthly income of Kshs 1,000.

He has received a loan of Kshs 10,000 from KADET. He will use this money to expand his farming by buying maize seeds worth Kshs 5,000 and fertilizer worth Kshs 5,000.

He has never borrowed from another source before KADET. Friends introduced him to this organization. Erustus operates his farming business in Kaptallam in Kabernet. His clients are residents of Kaptallam.

If this loan boosts his business, Erustus will use the extra income to expand his business. He dreams and hopes to buy a cow and thus venture into livestock farming. He describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: to purchase farming inputs

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Née le 23 Décembre 1979 à Bamako (capitale du Mali), Mariam Bouaré est mariée et mère 5 enfants. Elle réside avec son époux et leurs enfants à Wayerma I, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Mariam Bouaré, après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à cette activité d’achat et  de vente  des pagnes Wax, de chaussures, de tissus brodés, de concentrée de tomate etc, qu’elle achète à Bobo Dioulasso (république de Burkina Faso) il y a environ cinq ans. Elle mène son activité à son domicile et de façon ambulante dans la ville de Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a maintenant cinq an. Après  5 prêts solidaires dans un association des femmes de son quartier (Association DANAYA de Wayerma I), elle est à son premier individuel et tous ses   prêts solidaires ont été tous correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 20 paires de chaussures différentes, 8 pièces de pagne Wax, 5 complets de tissus brodés et 5 cartons de concentrée tomate. Ses marchandises sont vendues en détail, de façon ambulante, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée essentiellement des femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 120 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce de ses dépenses, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Born on December 23, 1979 in Bamako (capital of Mali), Ms. Mariam Bouaré is married and the mother of five children. She resides with her husband and their children in Wayerma I, one of the working-class district of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having worked in many businesses without success, she was introduced to this business, buying and selling wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), shoes, embroidered fabrics, tomato paste, etc. about five years ago. She gets her supplies in Bobo Dioulasso (Republic of Burkina Faso). She operates her business out of her home and by going door-to-door in Sikasso City, where she is much in demand for the quality of her products. To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, Mariam decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso five years ago. After five solidarity loans with a women's association in her district (Association DANAYA de Wayerma I), she is now on her first individual loan. All the preceding ones have been properly repaid. She plans on using this loan to buy 20 pairs of various shoes, 8 bolts of Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), 5 outfits of embroidered fabrics, and 5 boxes of tomato paste. Her goods are sold retail, cash or credit accepted, by going door-to-door. Her customer base is composed essentially of women. With this loan, Mariam envisions making a monthly profit of 120,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to increase her working capital, to help cover family expenses, and to pay the loan interest.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is 35 years old, married with a child. She is a happy and hard working woman. Mercy is a LAPO client. Mercy has a poultry farm where she rears birds to sell. She loves this business because it is highly profitable. Mercy hopes to expand her poultry business. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more birds. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more poultry birds

loans.name: Francis Koem

texts.en:
Francis Komen C. is a single, 26-year-old, commercial farmer. He started his business 2 years ago and makes a monthly profit of Kshs 3,600. 

He has received a loan of Kshs 10,000 from KADET. This loan will be used to expand his farming business as he plans to buy more farm inputs to expand production. Francis has never borrowed from another source before KADET. A friend, who is a KADET client, introduced him to this organization.

Francis‘s farm is in Kaptallam. His clients are business women who sell groceries to the nearby college.

If this loan boosts his business, Francis will use the extra profit to improve his living standards. He hopes and dreams of transforming his farming from crop to livestock. He describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena F. is from the town of Banga. She is 50 years old. Elena is married and has six adult children. To make a living, Elena owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also manages a small sari-sari store that she hopes to grow, too. Elena has been engaged in her business for over 12 years.

In 2010, Elena joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elena is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure and additional store merchandise. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elena from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance, and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and additional store merchandise

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph C. is 36 years old and married to Janet C. who is a business lady. They have one child, Jepchumba, 7 months old.

Joseph owns a shop, which he started six years ago. The shop gives him a monthly profit of Kshs 12,000. Joseph also has a workshop which gives him a profit of  Kshs 5,0000 monthly. Joseph's business is in Seretunin. His clients are residents of this area.

He has borrowed a loan of Kshs 15,000 from KADET. This is Joseph's first source of funds from a financial institution. He will use Kshs 7,000 to expand the shop and Kshs 8,000 for the expansion of the workshop.

If this loan boosts his business, Joseph will use the extra profit to expand his business.  Joseph dreams and hopes to own a big business.  He describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase stock for the workshop

loans.name: Henry Kipsang

texts.en:
Henry Kipsang L. is a married man, 35 years old and blessed with one beautiful child. He is a maize farmer and lives in Sinonin in Eldoret. He sells maize after the harvest and gets a monthly income of 3,000 Kenya shillings. Henry has been farming for 10 years now. He also owns a posho mill in the same area. 

Henry came to know about KADET through other groups in the area where he lives.

This will be Henry's first loan with KADET, and he plans to use the entire loan to buy fertilizer and maize seedlings, and hire help to plow his land. His dream is to become a better farmer and to farm a bigger land, eventually increasing his two-acre plot of land to six acres so that he can increase his monthly income and raise his family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy farm inputs and hire help to plow his land

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Madame Mariam S. est née le 03 Novembre 1977 à Kiffosso sous-préfecture de Yorosso (cercle de Koutiala). Mère de 2 enfants,elle a son époux  en aventure en Angleterre, alors elle réside avec ses deux enfants chez son père à Kamalen Sirakoro, un des  villages périphériques de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Mariam S.  mène il y a environ dix  ans  l’activité d’achat et de vente  des pagnes Wax,  de chaussures ,  de tissus brodés,  de balaies, etc. Elle mène son activité à son domicile et de façon ambulante dans la ville de Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis 5 ans.  Après  plusieurs prêts solidaires dans une association des femmes de sa localité, elle est à son  premier prêt individuel qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 5 pièces de pagne wax, 20 paires de chaussures de qualités différentes, 2 cartons de savon en poudre et des balaies. Elle achète ses marchandises sur place et à Bobo Dioulasso (république de Burkina Faso) avant de les revendre en détail, de façon ambulante, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée essentiellement des femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 85 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Mariam S. was born on November 3, 1977 in Kiffosso sub-prefecture of Yorosso (Cercle de Koutiala). She is the mother of two children. Her husband is abroad in England, and so she resides with her two children at her father's place in Kamalen Sirakoro, a village on the outskirts of Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). For about ten years, she has had a business buying and selling Wax pagnes (colorful West African cloth), shoes, embroidered fabrics, brooms, etc. She operates out of her home and by going door-to-door in Sikasso City, where she is much in demand by her customers for the quality of her goods. To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, Mariam decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso five years ago. After several solidarity loans with a women's association in her town, she is now on her first individual loan. This loan will be used to buy 5 bolts of Wax pagnes, 20 pairs of shoes of different qualities, 2 boxes of powdered soap, and some brooms. She buys her merchandise locally and in Bobo Dioulasso (Republic of Burkina Faso). Accepting cash or credit, she then sells them retail, by going door-to-door, to a customer base composed essentially of women. With this loan, she envision making a monthly profit of 85,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to help cover family expenses, to pay the loan interest, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Elyn

texts.en:
Elyn N. is from the town of Banga. She is 27 years old. Elyn is married and has one infant child. To make a living, Elyn owns & operates a business raising crops and ducks. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also earns from the eggs produced by her ducks. Elyn has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Elyn joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elyn is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elyn from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Barnaba Kiptalam

texts.en:
Barnaba is 32 years old and married to Jepkemoi Kandie.  They live in Abases and have two children: Hilda (10 years old; in Standard 5) and Damaris (5 years old; in Top Class).

Barnaba runs a retail shop, which he started 10 years ago. He earns a profit of Kshs 10,000 from this business and Kshs 5,000 from other sources. He has borrowed a loan of Kshs 60,000, which he wants to use to start farming to supplement his retail shop income. He will purchase three dairy cows, napier grass and hire labor. He has never borrowed a loan from other sources. Existing members introduced him to KADET.

If this loan boosts his business, Barnaba will use the extra profit to fulfill his hopes and dreams of purchasing land. He describes himself as hardworking and committed to succeeding.

loans.use: To purchase dairy cows and other farm inputs

loans.name: Beth

texts.en:
Beth is a 43-year-old lady who is widowed and has two children. She sells mineral water and juices wholesale. She is also employed as a sales representative by a fruit processing company. For this reason, she has employed one person who helps her run her business. Beth also farms to earn more income to support her family.

Beth is a member of Matel group in Faulu Kenya. Being an active member of the group, she attends the weekly meetings and saves part of her income. She has been able to request a loan of Kes 80,000 from Faulu Kenya because she has been guaranteed by the other group members. She plans to use this loan to buy mineral water and juices for sale.

Beth hopes to improve her standard of living and invest more in her business. She dreams of owning trucks for transporting her products to her clients.

loans.use: To buy more mineral water and juices

loans.name: Ezekiel Tallam

texts.en:
Ezekiel is 60 years old and is married to Kobilo C.. They have eight children: Simon (30 years old; O-level graduate), Johnstone ( 26 years old ; O-level graduate), William (24 years old; O-level graduate), Gladys (22 years old; student), Jepchumba (18 years old; student), Jeruto (14 years old; student), Eric (28 years old, O-level graduate) and Jemutai (20 years old, student).

Ezekiel operates a hotel (restaurant) which he started four years ago and earns a monthly profit of Ksh 2,000 from this business. His farm also supplements what he earns from the hotel.

Ezekiel has borrowed Ksh 24,000 from KADET. He will use the loan to cultivate his farm, buy maize seed and fertilizer, and purchase fungicides and pesticides.

Ezekiel has not borrowed from another source before KADET. Existing clients introduced him to KADET.

If this loan boosts his business, Ezekiel will use the extra profit to expand his horticultural business and educate his children to higher levels. His dreams and hopes are to buy a tractor for cultivation and also become a dairy farmer. He describes himself as a hardworking and honest person.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs like seed, fertilizer, fungicide and pesticide

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace sells drinks in Benin City, Edo state. She hopes to be a major drink distributor in the future. She is a LAPO client. She is 57 years old, married with 6 children. Her husband also works to support their home. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Anecito

texts.en: Anecito R. is from the town of Banga. He is 60 years old, is a widower, and has seven adult children. Anecito owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over forty years. In 2010, Anecito joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. This loan will be his first from CEVI. Anecito plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer such as manure

loans.name: Haron Kipkulei

texts.en:
Haron Kipkulei T. is 57 years old and married to Selly Sortich who is 37 years old. They live in Kaptimbor and have seven children.

Haron is a shoemaker and has been in this business for twelve years. His shoemaking shop is in Kabarnet, where local and nearby residents are his clients. The venture generates a monthly profit of Kshs 3,000 and from other sources he gets Kshs 1,000 monthly.

Haron has borrowed Kshs 5,000 from KADET. From this loan, Kshs 2,000 will be used to purchase shoe soles, Kshs 1,000 to purchase insoles, and Kshs 2,000 to purchase nails, thread and glue.

Haron previously borrowed from K.I.E (Kenya Industrial Estates). Existing clients introduced him to KADET.

If this loan boosts his business, Haron will use the extra profit to plant maize and beans and venture into dairy farming. His hope and dream is to be a dairy farmer. He describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase shoe soles and others materials for mending and making shoes

loans.name: Rose Jerotich

texts.en:
Rose is a single, 38-year-old lady who runs a boutique in Kabartonjo in Kabernet, Kenya. Residents of Kabartonjo are her clients and she makes a profit of Kshs 9,000.

Rose has borrowed Kshs 40,000 from KADET. She will use Kshs 20,000 to purchase new clothes, Kshs 12,000 to open a fruit store, Kshs 6,000 to purchase a blender and Kshs 2,000 to pay for labor.

Rose was introduced to KADET by one of its clients. If this loan boosts her business, Rose will use the extra profit to open another fruit outlet. Her hope and dream is to open a shoe shop. Rose describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase stock for her clothing boutique, open a fruit store, purchase a blender and pay for labor

loans.name: Nyetaa Group

texts.fr:
Les six femmes du groupe Nyetaa sont toutes mariées dans des familles monogames ayant en  moyenne 36 ans, 3 enfants et habitant toutes  le quartier Hamdallaye, Commune Urbaine de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali).
Ce groupe de femmes qui est lié par des liens de parenté et de mariage, s’est spécialisé dans les activités de teinture et vente d’articles teints. 
Elles  sont à leur 11ème prêt solidaire après avoir correctement remboursé sans faille les  10 précédents. 
Madame Safiatou H. qui est la présidente pratique cette activité de teinture et vente de bazins teints il y a 30ans. Elle offre ses services de teinture à qui en a besoin et assure la formation des jeunes femmes qui le désirent. Madame Safiatou H. jouit d’une grande réputation pour la qualité et le sérieux dans son travail. 
Elle utilisera son montant pour acheter : 40 pièces de Bazin dont 2 pièces de Bazin riche, 30kg de soude caustique, une douzaine de sachets de divers colorants, 1carton de savon de lessive, et 10kg de sel. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako. 
Pour teindre un Bazin il faut préalablement présenter les motifs sur le tissu puis faire dissoudre la quantité de soude caustique qu’il faut, faire le mélange de couleurs nécessaires, le bouillir, le laisser tremper, le laver au besoin, le faire sécher; le battre jusqu’à le rendre lisse et brillant. 
Elle revend ses produits à domicile et sur commande à Bamako et Dakar à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femmes, au comptant et à crédit. 
Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 95.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour, rembourser son prêt, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, participer aux évènements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes, funérailles).
texts.en:
The six women of the group Nyetaa are all married in monogamous families, and they average 36 years of age and three children all living in the Hamdallaye district, in the urban community of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). This group of women, who are linked by ties of kinship and marriage, became specialized in the businesses of dying cloth and selling the items to do so. The group members are on their eleventh solidarity loan after having properly repaid without fail the ten preceding ones. Ms. Safiatou H., who is the president of the group, has been operating her business dying cloth and selling the dyed damask for thirty years. She offers her dye services to anyone who needs them, and she ensures the training of the young women who want the training. She enjoys a great reputation for quality and seriousness in her work. Safiatou will use her sum for buying: 40 bolts of damask cloth, including 2 bolts of "riche" damask, 30 kg of caustic soda, a dozen pouches of various dyes, a box of laundry soap, and 10 kg of salt. She gets her supplies in Bamako. To dye damask cloth, the motifs must be introduced onto the cloth ahead of time. And then the necessary quantity of caustic soda is dissolved with the necessary colors. It is all mixed, boiled, left to soak, washed as needed, dried, and pounded until the cloth is smooth and shiny. Accepting cash or credit, Safiatou sells her products at home and by special order in Bamako and Dakar to a customer base composed of women and men. She hopes to make a monthly profit of 95,000 francs CFA that will be used to repay her loan, to help cover family expenses, and to take part in societal events (marriages, baptisms, funerals).

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying white damask cloth and supplies for dying cloth

loans.name: Charles Yator

texts.en:
Charles is 61 years old and married to Linah Yator. They live in Kabarnet Town and have five children: Sylvia (29 years: O-level graduate), Lucy (27 years; in college), Chesire (15 years; in primary school), Mathew (13 years; in primary school), and Kiplimo (10 years; in primary school).

Charles is a farmer. He started this business ten years ago and makes a monthly profit of Kshs 10,000. His clients are supportive and faithful. His salary provides him with additional income.

Charles has borrowed Kshs 20,000 from KADET. Kshs 10,000 will be used to buy fertilizer, Kshs 5,000 will be used to buy bean seeds, and Kshs 5,000 will be used for cultivation and fencing.

If this loan boosts his business, Charles will use the extra profit to educate his children and also construct a bigger house for his family. His hope and dream is to become a famous businessman. He describes himself as an honest and hardworking man.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs like seed, fertilizer and fencing

loans.name: Tièssiri Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Tièssiri est composé de quatre femmes toutes mariées dans des familles monogames. Elles ont un âge moyen de 29 ans avec 2 enfants. Elles habitent toutes  le quartier Darsalam, Commune Urbaine de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali)  et se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage,  d’amitié et de mariage.
 Ce groupe qui fait le commerce d’articles divers  et est à son 3ème  prêt solidaire avec Soro Yiriwaso. Les membres de Tièssiri vendent  des habits : des tissus brodés, du Bazin, des draps de lit et  des produits de beauté. 
Madame Kame M.  est le membre qui évolue dans le créneau de la cosmétique avec  l’achat vente de  produits de  beauté, des parfums et de l’encens. 
Elle utilisera son prêt pour acheter : 10cartons crèmes, 6 cartons de lait et de tubes, 5 cartons de parfums et déodorants de différentes variétés. 
Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako et quelques fois à Ségou. Elle revend ses produits à domicile et  en ambulant. 
Sa clientèle est  composée essentiellement de femmes et  de quelques hommes.  Elle vend au comptant et crédit, elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 35.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour, rembourser son prêt et contribuer à certaines dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
The Tièssiri group consists of four married women from monogamous families. On average, they are 29 years old and have two children. They all live in the Darsalam neighborhood of the urban commune of Ségou (4th Administrative Region of Mali) where they are well-known by virtue of their neighborhood, friendship and marriage connections. This group trades in several different lines of merchandise and is repaying its third joint loan from Soro Yiriwaso. Its members sell clothing, embroidered cloth, damask, bed linens and beauty products. Mme Kame M. is the member who is developing a market in cosmetics, buying and selling beauty products, perfumes and incense. She plans on using her loan to buy ten packages of creams, ten packages of milk in tubes, five packages of perfumes, and several different deodorants. She buys in Bamako, and occasionally in Ségou. She sells from her home and by going door-to-door. . Mostly her customers are women, but a few are men. She sells for cash and on credit, and hopes for a monthly income of 35,000FCFA to be used to pay back her loan and to help pay family expenses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetics

loans.name: Cynthiah

texts.en:
Cynthiah runs a retail shop where she sells cereals. She has been in this business for five years. She also farms to earn extra income to support her family. Her husband is employed in a poultry distributor company.

“Jambo Kisaju” is her group in Faulu Kenya and she is an active member who attends their weekly meetings. Through the group meetings, the members share business ideas, save money, and also guarantee each other’s loans.

Cynthiah has requested a loan of Kes 30,000 to buy more cereals and maize flour to sell. She hopes to provide a quality education for her children. For this reason, she strives hard in her business to provide a brighter future for her children.

loans.use: To buy more cereals and maize flour to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary sells drinks in Benin City, Edo state. She hopes to be a major drink distributor in the future. She is a LAPO client. She is 48 years old, married with 5 children. Her husband also works to support their home. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 70,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Omolabanke

texts.en:
Omolabanke is a faithful LAPO client and has been a member for some years with good record. She buys and sells drinks in wholesale and retail price and has been in the business for over 10 years.  
She hopes for more capital into the business in order to meet the demand of her numerous costumers in her locality. She is requesting for a loan of NGN70, 000 to purchase more drinks to sell and maximize profit. 

Omolabanke is 55years old, married and bless with four children. Her husband is into welding and they work hard to cater for their family.  She expresses her gratitude to all lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkan de l’association Benkadi est composé de 4 femmes mariées de la ville de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies. Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage, la  parenté et exercent ensemble  des activités génératrices de revenus il y’ a environ 5 ans et font entre autre le commerce de condiments alimentaires, de boissons  et aussi des divers. Elles ont en moyenne 32 ans et au moins 7 enfants. 
Le groupe a intégré l’institution de microfinance il y’ a une année et  est à son deuxième prêt solidaire. 
Quant à l’utilisation du prêt Rokiatou Traoré, qui est la présidente du groupe,  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 50 casiers de boissons sucreries de toutes sortes pour les mettre dans le réfrigérateur et revend  en détail et en espèce.
Elle s’approvisionne chez le dépositaire de la place et sa clientèle est composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Tandis que Rokiatou espère réaliser un bénéfice de 28000FCFA, les autres membres envisagent obtenir 23000 FCFA. Ces bénéfices seront utilisés pour subvenir aux dépenses familiales et réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The Benkan group of the Benkadi association is composed of four married women from San, a town in Ségou Region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in large extended traditional families and got acquainted through bonds of community and kinship. For about five years, they've been running businesses together, selling, among others, food condiments, beverages, and various items. They average 32 years of age and have at least seven children. The group joined Kiva's partner, the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso one year ago, and it is now seeking its second solidarity loan (group loan). Regarding the use of the loan, Rokiatou Traoré, the group president, intends to use it to buy 50 boxes of soft drinks, thats she refrigerates and retails for cash. She gets her supplies from authorized dealers in her town, and her clientele comprises women and men. She hopes to turn a profit of XOF 28'000 (ca US$ 54), whereas the other members foresee XOF 23'000 (ca US$ 44). The profits will be used in part to pay for the family expenses, and in part reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy soft drinks

loans.name: Eunice Jematia

texts.en:
Eunice is a single, 28-year-old lady who lives in Kabarnet Town.

Eunice sells shoes and from this business she gets a profit of Kshs 5,000 every month. She gets additional income from farming. Her business is in Kabarnet Town along Chelagat Road. Her clients pay in cash and are faithful.

Eunice has borrowed Kshs 20,000 from KADET. She will use Kshs 10,000 to buy sports shoes, Kshs 5,000 to buy open shoes for ladies, and Kshs 5,000 to buy school shoes for both boys and girls.

KADET is the first financial institution from which Eunice has borrowed. Existing clients introduced her to KADET. If this loan boosts her business, she will use the extra profit to expand her business widely.

Eunice’s hopes and dreams are to own a plot of land, a personal car, and to one day construct rental houses. She describes herself as faithful, accountable, responsible, God-fearing and hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her shoe business

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en:
Roseline is 32 years old and is married with four children. In the last two years, she has been selling secondhand clothes and shoes to earn a living. Since she opened up her business, it has been picking up gradually. She uses her income to educate her three children and support her husband in paying the household expenses.

Roseline has been an active member of a group in Faulu Kenya where she saves her money. Her group members have guaranteed her a loan of Kes 40,000 which she requested from Faulu Kenya. She intends to use this loan to add to her stock of clothes and shoes.

Roseline dreams of expanding her business so that she can be financially stable.

loans.use: To add to her stock of clothes and shoes

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkan de l’association Fotemogoban est composé de 7 femmes  mariées de la ville de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Les membres du groupe Benkan vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles.  Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage et la  parenté. Elles ont en moyenne 45 ans et au moins 8 enfants.
Les membres de ce groupe ont une expérience solide dans le petit commerce qui tourne autour de l’alimentaire et de l’habillement. 
Ces femmes du groupe a décidé d’intégrer le programme  crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis 2009 et sont à leur 2ème  prêt  solidaire. 
La présidente du groupe qui est Assa Moriké Touré compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter,  60 caisses de poisson frais à Talon barrage pour partir revendre à Bamako en gros et en espèce,  de retour elle  s’approvisionne en  bijoux qui seront vendus à San en espèce et à crédit. 
Elle envisage obtenir un bénéfice mensuel de 25 000 FCFA et les autres membres du groupe eux  espèrent sur un profit de 23 000 FCFA par qui seront utilisé pour rembourser le prêt venir en secours aux conjoints et développer les activités en diversifiant les produits.
texts.en:
