The Benkan group of the Fotemogoban association is composed of seven married women of San, a town in Ségou Region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The members of the Benkan group live in large traditional families. They got acquainted through bonds of community and kinship. They average 45 years of age and have at least 8 children. The members of this group have a solid experience in the retailing food products and clothing. In 2009, the women of the group decided to join the loan program of Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso. They are now seeking their second solidarity loan (group loan). The group's president, Assa Moriké Touré, intends to use her loan to buy 60 boxes of fresh fish at Talon dam, that she will then bring to Bamako and resell, wholesale and for cash. She will then buy jewelry to resell in San, for cash and on credit. She foresees turning a monthly profit of XOF 25'000 (ca US$ 48), whereas the other members hope to make XOF 23'000 (ca US$ 44). The profits will be used to repay the loan, help their husbands, and bolster their businesses by diversifying the products they sell.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell various food products and clothing

loans.name: Aean

texts.en: Mrs. Aean C. is 53 years old and lives in the village of Tuol Svay in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a four-hectare plot of land on which she makes a living by growing rice. To better run her farm, Mrs. Aean C. has applied for a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide. In addition to farming, she also earns a small additional income from making rice wine. Mrs. Aean C. is widow with six children; two help her work and the other four are still in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide for her farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying grocery items

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose C. is 37 years old and married to Laban Chebii who is a 47-year-old teacher. They live in Kabarnet and have four children: Kipsang (11 years old; in primary school), Dorcas (9 years old; in primary school), Dorcas (7 years old; in primary school) and Gilbert (4 years old; in pre-school).

Rose sells mitumba (used) clothes and her business is in Kabarnet Market. Her clients pay in cash and are very supportive and faithful. She started this business two years ago and earns a monthly profit of Kshs 10,000. Her husband’s salary brings in additional income.

Rose has borrowed Kshs 20,000 from KADET and will use the loan to purchase skirts, shirts, vests, jackets, and jumpers. She has never borrowed from another source before KADET. She learned about KADET through inquiring at its office.

If this loan boosts her business, Rose will use the extra profit to educate her children and expand her business. Her hope and dream is to become a very rich and famous businesswoman with her own car. She describes herself as a hardworking and God-fearing woman.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her used-clothing business

loans.name: Omolara

texts.en:
Omolara is 40 years old, married and has a child. She and her family live in Lagos. She is hardworking and has been borrowing from LAPO for some years. She make clothes in different styles and has three apprentices with her at the shop. She also sells tailoring materials, sarongs and other accessories and has been in this business for over fifteen years. She makes sure customers demands are met while indirectly improving herself financially.
Omolara is requesting for a loan of NGN100, 000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She thank lenders for their good work.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell.

loans.name: Seab

texts.en: Mrs. Seab U. is 54 years old and lives in the village of Tuol Svay in Takeo province. She makes a living by growing rice on her two-hectare farm. To increase the size and quality of her crop, she has applied for a loan to buy a pump to water her crops, fertilizer and pesticide. and to hire a laborer to plow her field. Mrs. Seab U. is widow with two children; one is a farmer who helps her, and other sells groceries in the village market.

loans.use: To buy a water pump, fertilizer and pesticide and to hire laborer

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John M., 39, lives in Koyoin with his wife, Mary Chebon, and their six children: Cherop (13 years old; Class 6), Jepkemei (11 years old; Class 6), Yatich (9 years old), Betty (7 years old: Class 2), Purity (4 years old) and Kandie (2 years old).

John runs a hotel in Koyoin in Kabernet, earning a monthly profit of Kshs 3000. His wife is a farmer. Having been introduced to KADET by existing clients, John has requested his first loan of Kshs 15,000 to plant millet and hire labour for the farm and will save for future use any extra profits accruing from the loan. Describing himself as hardworking, John dreams of opening a big hotel in the future.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Espoir Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Espoir de l’association Charlie Espoir est composé de 7 femmes mariées de la ville de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage, la  parenté et ont en moyenne  32 ans et  3 enfants. 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso. Les membres du groupe Espoir font des activités génératrices de revenus il y’a de cela 5 ans, elles achètent  des tissus, des chaussures et bien d’autres articles divers. 
Charlotte S., qui est la présidente du groupe est le membre qui excelle dans l’achat vente de chaussures de toutes sortes. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, en  Côte d‘Ivoire, 32 cartons de chaussures en plastiques pour homme et femme. Elle vend dans les écoles et  marchés en espèce et à crédit. 
Tandis que Charlotte S. espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 28000 FCFA les autres membres du groupe envisagent obtenir 22000FCFA.
Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour subvenir aux dépenses familiales et réinvestir dans les activités.
texts.en:
The group Espoir of the association Charlie Espoir is composed of seven married women of the city of San, Region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali) who live in large traditional families.  The group members know one another through ties of community and kinship, and they average 32 years of age and three children.  They know one another through ties of community and kinship. The group members are on their first collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  They have had income-generating businesses for five years now and sell cloth, shoes, and many other diverse goods.  Charlotte S., who is the president of the group, is the member who excels in buying and selling shoes of all kinds.  She plans on using her loan to buy, from Cote d'Ivoire, 32 boxes of plastic footwear for men and women.  Accepting cash or credit, she makes her sales at schools and marketplaces.  While Charlotte hopes to make a monthly profit of 28,000 francs CFA, the other group members envision making 22,000 francs.  This profit will be used to meet family expenses and to reinvest in the businesses.       

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying shoes

loans.name: Felister

texts.en:
Felister, 46 years old and married with six children, has owned a retail shop for seven years where she sells sodas, cooking fat, maize, beans, sugar and rice. She also sells clothes and operates a poultry farm to earn a living.

Felister is in Matel group in Faulu Kenya and previously took out a loan of Kes. 20,000 that was guaranteed by the group members. She is now requesting a loan of Kes. 50,000 to buy clothes, beans and maize for sale and hopes to expand her business into other areas and become a wholesaler in the future.

loans.use: To buy clothes, beans and maize

loans.name: Sunday

texts.en: Sunday is 64 years old, married with 7 children. He has a farm where he plants cassava; during harvest he sells the cassava to sellers. With the profits from his farm, he meets the basic needs of his family. He wants to grow his business. He hopes for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more cassava stem to sell.  He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cassava stem to plant

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchasing overstock products [for resale]

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To restock more alcoholic brands in her pub

loans.name: Philedimah Kavete

texts.en:
Philedimah, a 32-year-old business lady, is married to Alexander Kyalo, a machine operator, and they have two children, ten and four years old. For the past four years she has operated a business selling plastic basins and buckets to her clients in Kwale, Nairobi, earning a monthly profit of 12,000 Kenya shillings.

Introduced to KADET by an existing group member, Philedimah wants to use her loan to buy more plastic basins and buckets and add a greater variety of items including umbrellas, suitcases, and shoes. Describing herself as hardworking, her hope is to earn more profit from her stock of products.

loans.use: To increase her stock of plastic basins and buckets and also buy umbrellas for sale.

loans.name: Thoeurn's Group

texts.en: This loan group consists of 13 people located in Kor village in Takeo province. It's elected leader is Mrs. Thoeurn S., 29. Each member of the group will use the loan for a different purpose. Mrs. Thoeurn S. and her husband, Mr. Mao Mark, are farmers who own 1.20 hectares of land to cultivate rice for a living. Mrs. Thoeurn S. also breeds pigs at home. In order to support her pig business, she is asking for a loan to buy pig food. Mrs. Thoeurn S. is the mother of two children — one is student in the local school while the youngest is a year old.

loans.use: To buy pig food

loans.name: Finesse Group

texts.fr:
Finesse  est un regroupement de femmes de l’association Fotemogoban qui sont toutes mariées, avec une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans et 5 enfants. Elles vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies  dans la ville de San, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Les membres du groupe Finesse se  sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage,  de  parenté et sont à leur  deuxième collaboration avec Soro Yiriwaso. 
Elles font le commerce de condiments, de diverses marchandises et calebasses. Elles s’approvisionnent à San, à Bla et dans les différentes foires  environnantes. 
Nana K., est le membre du groupe qui vend  les calebasses. Elle s’approvisionne à Bla pour revendre à San et  dans les foires.  
Elle compte acheter avec son prêt ci,  24 colis de calebasses.  
Avec une clientèle composée essentiellement de  femmes Nana K. vend en espèce et à crédit et espère réaliser mensuellement  un bénéfice de 13000FCFA et les autres membres du groupe comptent sur un bénéfice de 11500FCFA.
Ces bénéfices seront utilisés pour rembourser le prêt, subvenir aux besoins familiaux et réinvestir dans l’entreprise.
texts.en:
Finesse is a group of women of the association Fotemogoban who are all married.  They average 32 years of age and five children living in large traditional extended families in the city of San, Region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The group members know one another through ties of community and kinship, and they are now on their second collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso.  The group members do commerce in condiments, various goods, and calabashes.  They get their supplies in San, in Bla, and at the different fairs in the area.  Nana K. is the member of the group who sells calabashes.  She stocks up in Bla and sells in San and at the fairs.  She intends to use her loan to buy 24 packages of calabashes.  With a customer base composed essentially of women, Nana accepts cash or credit for her sales and hopes to make a monthly profit of 130,000 francs CFA. And the other group members plan on a profit of 115,000 francs.  These profits will be used to repay the loan, to provide for the family, and to reinvest in the enterprise. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying calabashes

loans.name: Stellamaris Mumbua

texts.en: Stellamaris, a 37-year-old married business lady with four children, has a shop in Tassia, Nairobi where she sells a variety of sweets and snacks which give her a monthly profit of 6,000 Kenyan Shillings.  Introduced to KADET by an existing group member, she wants to use her loan to expand her business by buying more sweets and snacks to sell in the highly populated area.  very hardworking, Stellamaris hopes to open many shops in the future and make more profit.

loans.use: To add a variety of sweets and snacks for sale

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en: Patricia sells loaves of bread in Benin City, Edo state. She has been in this business for long and she uses her experience in business to attract and retain more customers. She is married with 4 children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy. She is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more loaves of bread to sell. She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more loaves of bread to sell

loans.name: Evalyne

texts.en:
Evalyne is a hardworking lady who owns a retail shop where she sells sugar, cereals and cooking fat. In addition, she is a farmer. Evalyne was previously selling charcoal before she ventured into her retail shop business which she has been running for two years.

Evalyne is a member of Farasi (horse) SHG (self-help group) in Faulu Kenya whose members have guaranteed her loan of Kes 60,000. She plans to use this loan to buy cereals, sugar and rice for her shop.

Evalyne hopes to open a savings account with Faulu Kenya in the future. She dreams of enlarging her business into a wholesale operation.

loans.use: To buy cereals, sugar and rice

loans.name: Anna Kamanthe

texts.en:
Anna is a 39-year-old business lady who is widowed and has one child, 8 years old. She has an embroidery shop where she makes curtains and seat covers to sell to her clients in Tassia, Nairobi. Anna’s business gives her a monthly profit of 40,000 Kenyan shillings.

Anna was introduced to KADET by an existing group and wants to use her loan to buy raw materials (lace, embroidery thread, etc.) for her business.

Anna wants to grow her business and open a branch in Tassia where she intends to use her profits to buy a piece of land and a car. She is hardworking and independent.

loans.use: To buy materials for her embroidery shop

loans.name: Siguikafo Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Siguikafo de l’association Balemayaton est composé de 4 femmes mariées de la ville de  San région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Les membres du groupe Siguikafo vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelle et se sont connues à travers le voisinage. Elles ont en moyenne 40ans et au moins 6 enfants. 
Elles exercent le commerce depuis plusieurs années et ont intégré le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y’ a une année. Elles sont à leur 2è prêt solidaire. 
Elles font l’achat vente  des produits cosmétiques, de tissus wax à l’image de Djeneba D. et  des condiments alimentaires. 
Djeneba D. qui a un  kiosque au grand marché de San compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 20 balles de  tissus wax contenant chacune  50 pièces. 
Elle compte réaliser 15 000 FCFA de bénéfice par mois qui sera utilisé pour rembourser, subvenir aux besoins familiaux et réinvestir dans les activités.
texts.en:
The group Siguikafo of the association Balemayaton is composed of four married women of the city of San, Region of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  The group members, averaging 40 years of age and six children, live in large traditional families, and they know one another through community ties.  They have operated businesses for several years.  They joined the Soro Yiriwaso loan program a year ago and are now on their second solidarity loan.  The group members buy and sell cosmetics, wax cloth (as does Djeneba D.), and also condiments.  Djeneba D., who has a stall at the big market of San, intends to use her loan to buy 20 bales of wax cloth each containing 50 lengths of cloth.  She plans on making 15,000 francs CFA in profit per month that will be used for repaying the loan, for meeting family needs, and for reinvesting in the businesses. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cloth

loans.name: Tenuun

texts.en:
Tenuun is a humble, helpful and open-minded person. He lives with his wife, Tserenchimeg, and 2-year-old daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. They all live together in his house.

Tenuun currently operates a transportation business in the city using a van he owns. Every day, he makes nine trips between two transportation terminals in the city. His wife works along with him, collecting fares and announcing stops as he drives. They enjoy the work but his wife's voice is starting to tire after years of loudly announcing route stops.

Tenuun started his business in 2005 after obtaining a loan to purchase his van. He has found much success as a driver. However, he recently had to purchase a bus as the city government plans to enact a law forbidding the use of vans for transportation in the city.

Tenuun is requesting a loan to purchase a new van motor and four wheels to keep his van operating efficiently.

loans.use: To purchase a new van motor

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel is a LAPO client and he has good repayment record. He is 38 years old, married with 3 children. His wife sells foodstuffs to support their home. He sells VCDs (video compact disc) at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to expand his business in order to make more profits. He is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 150,000 to purchase more VCDs to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more VCDs to sell

loans.name: Zenewe Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Zenewe de l’association Benkadi est composé de 4 femmes mariées de la ville de San, région de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali). Les membres du groupe vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage et la  parenté. 
Elles exercent  la vente de diverses marchandises telles les condiments alimentaires et la transformation  tels Jacqueline.
Jaqueline D. s’est spécialisée dans la transformation des graines de néré en Sounbala qu’elle vend. 
Elle s’approvisionne en graines de néré à la foire de Kimparana, une fois les graines arrivées Jaqueline les met dans une grande marmite en les faisant bouillir toute une soirée après cette activité  elle  met les graines cuites dans un grand panier et emballés fermement pendant 72 heures. Ces deux actions terminées elle les met  en  pâte dans le mortier pour bien mélangé, ensuite elle les coupe en petit morceaux. 
Jaqueline  a une clientèle constituée de femme et espère obtenir un bénéfice de 26 000 FCFA qui sera essentiellement  réinvestir dans les activités.
texts.en:
The “Zenewe” group of the Benkadi is composed of four married women in the town of San, Segou region (the fourth administrative region of Mali). The members of the group live in extended traditional families. They know each other as neighbors and relatives. They sell various goods such as food condiments and prepared foods, as for example, Jacqueline does. Jaqueline D. specializes in preparing "sounbala" [a West African condiment] by processing the seed pods of “néré” [a leguminous shrub whose seeds transformed into a local food products by cooking and fermenting]. She purchases her supply of néré seeds at the Kimparana market. Once she has bought the seeds, she put them in a big pot and boils them for the whole evening, after which she puts the cooked seeds in a big basket and keeps them tightly wrapped for 72 hours. After these two steps are done, she crushes the seeds into a paste in a mortar and cuts it into small pieces. Jacqueline has a customer based composed of women. She hopes to achieve a monthly income of 26,000 West African francs, which will be largely reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing the seeds of nere, an African shrub plant used in food production

loans.name: Jeremia

texts.en:
Jeremia is 35 years old and married to a teacher. He operates a taxi and also hires out cars. He has been in this business for just a year.

As well as this, Jeremia is employed and also does dairy farming. He divides his time between business and employment but he decided to employ one person in his taxi business.

Since Jeremia joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to save his money regularly and access loans. He has requested a loan of Kes 20,000 to buy new tires for his vehicle.

Jeremia hopes to expand his business and have several vehicles in the future. He dreams of venturing into a van transport business.

loans.use: To buy new tires for his vehicle

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying a mill

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en: Jackson is a LAPO client and he has good repayment record. He is 24 years old, married with a child. His wife also works to support their home. He sells groceries and drinks at retail prices to his customers. He hopes to expand his business in order to make more profits. He is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks

loans.name: Stellamaris

texts.en:
Stellamaris is a 33-year-old married lady with two children. She has been running a retail shop for three years where she sells foodstuffs. She was previously selling clothes before she ventured into this business. Her husband is employed in Tastic Enterprise Nrb and he supports her with the household expenses.

Stellamaris belongs to a group called “Blessed in Faulu Kenya” whose members guarantee each other’s loans. She wants to start a business selling clothes and hence she requested a loan of Kes 27,000 to buy clothes to sell.

Stellamaris hopes to expand her business into a wholesale operation so as to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: To start a new business selling clothes

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his business by buying more business goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying a refrigerator for his cafe

loans.name: Adeola

texts.en:
Adeola is 45years old has two children and lives with her family in Lagos State; she sells groceries like tomatoes paste, milk, tea and more to earn her living. She opens her shop everyday of the week in order to make more sales.  She has been in this business for the past of six years. With the proceeds from the business she could assist her husband in meeting the children’s need. 

She hopes for more expansion in future, she is requesting for a loan amount of NGN100, 000 to purchase more groceries to sell, increase profit and her ability to satisfy customers while improving her family financially.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell,

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter, 56, is married and has two children. He is a hardworking and determined man who does dairy farming for a living. Together with his wife, he has been farming for ten years. He also operates a retail shop to earn more income for supporting his family.

Peter is a member of “Lenres Group” in Faulu Kenya whose members guarantee each other’s loans. Since he joined the group, he has been able to save his money on a weekly basis and this has helped him invest in his business.

Peter has requested a loan of Kes 80,000 to buy a dairy cow and a calf. He hopes to be a large-scale farmer in the future. He dreams of owning a milk processing plant in ten years time.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow and a calf

loans.name: Alfred

texts.en:
Alfred O. is a small-business owner and a married man. He is a farmer keeping goats, a milk cow and pigs at Yombo Vituka ward in Dar es Salaam. He also runs a business selling furniture. The business income helps him to meet his daily family demand, paying school fees, and business capitalization.

Alfred is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,200,000 to expand his business.

loans.use: To expand his business by buying more business goods

loans.name: Bineta

texts.fr: Mademoiselle Bineta S. née en 1982 est vendeuse de céréales au marché khelcom de Thiès. C'est avec l'aide de sa maman qu'elle a ouvert une cantine au marché depuis le 05 Janvier 2009. Elle y vend des produits céréaliers du genre mil, maïs, sorgho, niébé et des aliments de bétail. Elle est à sa deuxième demande de crédit et sollicite pour cette fois un prêt de 100 000 FCFA pour dit-elle renforcer son activité de commerce
texts.en:
Ms. Bineta S., born in 1982, is a retailer of grains at the Khelcom market of Thiès.  With her mother's help, she opened a stall at the market on January 5, 2009.  There, she sells these kinds of grain:  millet, corn, sorghum, black-eyed peas, and animal fodder.  She is on her second loan request, and this time she is requesting a loan of 100,000 francs CFA.  She says this is for bolstering her commerce.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies of a variety of foodstuffs

loans.name: Bukono Kwetungura, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
There is a fascinating story behind determined A. Robina who is not afraid of diversity in the business sector. This hardworking married mother of two children began her a retail shop dealing in general merchandise twelve years ago in Bukono, Kihihi. Through acquiring loans from micro-finance institutions, she was able to start up this side business to help her generate more income for the family alongside her tea-growing farm.

With this loan Robina will be able to purchase more goods and be able to improve her stock and earnings as she looks forward to living a self-sustaining life.

loans.use: To restock her business with the motive of transforming it into a wholesale operation

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying grocery items

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina M. is a small-business owner and a married woman. She runs a business selling food, both cooked and fried, to customers at Tandika market in Dar es Salaam. She also sells soft drinks.

Amina purchases her business goods from the food shops and food market at Tandika. The business income enables her to pay her children’s school fees and meet her family’s daily needs.

Amina is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,000,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia A., 51, is making sure that her family has adequate provision for their daily needs. Married to Abraham, a mason, she is blessed with two children in her marriage. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She manages her own merienda (afternoon snack) business and variety store.

Alicia has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends its weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow five times from CCT’s cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.

To ensure the success of her businesses, Alicia would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding businesses by buying more products needed to replenish and maintain operation of her businesses.

Alicia dreams that her businesses will continue to grow so that she can provide a happy and comfortable life for her family.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional stock for her variety store and raw ingredients for her snacks business

loans.name: Khady

texts.fr:
Madame Khady S. sollicite auprès de sa caisse U-IMCEC un prêt de 200 000 FCFA. Pour cela, elle est passée à la caisse et nous renseigne sur son activité.
 « Je m’appelle Khady et  j’habite au quartier Grand Thiès. Je suis âgée de 35 ans et suis mère de 5 mignons enfants dont l’ainé compte en cette année 20 ans.
C’était il y’a 4 ans où j’avais senti que l’oisiveté me dominait et que j’étais très inactive que j’ai décidé de me lancer dans le commerce de fruits. Actuellement mon activité était marche, je rends grâce à Dieu. Je vends mes marchandises à coté de la gare routière sise à l’entrée de Thiès.
Animée par un besoin de renforcer mon activité et d’augmenter ma production, je viens  solliciter un prêt de 200 000 FCFA  pour m’approvisionner en marchandises. Et j’espère que vous allez me octroyer (s’adressant à l’agent de crédit…. rire..) »
Cependant, Madame Khady S. est très connue dans son milieu de travail et elle est à sa deuxième demande crédit.
texts.en:
Ms. Khady S. is requesting from her U-IMCEC branch office a loan of  200,000 francs CFA.  Towards this, she came by the office and informed us about her business.  "My name is Khady, and I live in the district of Grand Thiès.  I am 35 years old and the mother of five cute children.  The oldest is 20 this year.  Four years ago, when I felt that idleness was dominant in my life and that I was very inactive, I decided to start a business in fruit.  Lately, my business has been operating, and I thank God.  I sell merchandise next to the bus station at the entrance to Thiès.  Guided by a need to bolster my business and to increase my production, I am here to request a loan of 200,000 francs for stocking up on merchandise.  And I hope that you will me grant the loan (while addressing herself to the loan agent... with a laugh)." Ms. Khady S. is well-known in her area of work, and she is on her second loan request. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies of merchandise

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima P. is a married businesswoman. She is a farmer keeping poultry at Yombo Buza ward in Dar es Salaam. She keeps broilers (for meat). Her poultry farm consists of poultry cages partitioned where chicks are kept. The business income generated is used to meet the daily family needs and capitalize the business. She is requesting a loan of T.shs 1,000,000 to further capitalize the business.

loans.use: To buy more business goods to boost the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchasing a mill

loans.name: Wofugan

texts.en: Wofugan C. is a small entrepreneur and a married man. He runs a food shop at Yombo Vituka in Dar es Salaam. He purchases and sells various food crop products including wheat flour, maize flour, beans, sugar, cooking oil and soaps. He purchases the business goods from the wholesale shops at the city market center at Kariakoo and directly from the food crop suppliers wholesale. Business income helps him to meet daily family needs and capitalize the business. He is requesting a loan of T.shs 1,200,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more goods for resale

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy B., 30, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Napoleon B., a factory worker, she is blessed with one child in their marriage. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own variety store while selling electronic cellular phone load for quite some time now.

Daisy has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow six times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her variety store.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 12,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business, buying groceries, toiletries and beverages necessary to replenish stocks in her store. A portion of the loan will also be invested into buying phone load for different networks.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying groceries, toiletries and beverages and phone load for different networks

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Laila

texts.en:
Laila S. is a 45-year-old Palestinian woman from Ramallah. She owns a clothing and accessories store in Ramallah, where she sells women's wear and accessories. The store is well known in the neighborhood and has its own clientele.

Laila took a $3000 loan from FATEN to start selling a different type of goods in her store in addition to the women wear and accessories. Laila wants to add toys and dolls for children, as well as children's wear, to her store. She believes this will increase demand for what she sells and yield a better income.

Laila stands in her store in the photo above.

loans.use: Add new goods to women's clothing store

loans.name: Winefreda

texts.en:
Winefreda N. is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Already a widow at 59, she is blessed with five children. She makes sure that she earns well so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own video game business for quite some time now.

Winefreda has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her business.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 13,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business, buying spare parts for the maintenance of computer and video games.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow and be successful.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying spare parts for the maintenance of video games

loans.name: Abuu

texts.en: Abuu A. is an entrepreneur and a married man with four school-going children. He runs a cosmetics shop at Yombo Kiwalani ward in Dar es Salaam. He purchases the business goods from wholesale and retail cosmetics shops at Kariakoo city shopping center and other shops around. He has managed to construct a residential house from the business income. He lives with his family in his house. He is requesting a loan of T.shs, 1,200,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: to buy business goods to expand the business

loans.name: Leliosa

texts.en:
Leliosa B., 33, is making sure that her family has enough for their daily needs. Married to Daniel B., a businessman, she is blessed with one child in their marriage. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own fruit stand while operating a hardware store selling mainly carpentry tools. She also raises a few hogs for additional income.

Leliosa has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times through CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 23,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business, buying more products to be sold at her hardware store to replenish her current product stock.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: buying more fruits to be incorporated into her current product inventory

loans.name: Aïssatou

texts.fr:
Pour son besoin de crédit au sein d’U-IMCEC Thiès, Madame Aïssatou S.  nous a livré cet entretien
Quelle est votre activité Madame ?
-	Madame Aïssatou : je fais le commerce de tissus, téléphone portable, lait, produits de lessive, tout ce qui marche en général  depuis 10 ans. Et je les place très souvent aux grossistes de Thiès et je vend rarement en détail
Comment vous avez choisi ce métier ?
-	Madame Aïssatou : J’ai vu les gens s’activaient dans le métier et c’était beaucoup plus facile de le faire, ça demande pas d’être très diplômée pour le faire. Donc mes paires m’ont poussées à le faire
Quelles sont les aspects les plus importants dans ce travail ?
-	Madame Aïssatou : l’approvisionnement. C’est pourquoi je m’approvisionne très souvent  en Nouakchott capitale de la Mauritanie où les marchandises sont moins chères.
A quoi sert ce crédit que vous demandez ?
-	Madame Aïssatou : Ce crédit, si vous me le donnez, va me permettre de m’approvisionner, développer et élargir mon business.
Madame Aïssatou est à sa troisième demande de crédit au niveau de la caisse. Elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants
texts.en:
For her borrowing needs at the micro-finance institution U-IMCEC Thiès, Ms. Aïssatou S. provided us this interview:  What is your business, Madame ? -    Madame Aïssatou : For ten years, I have been doing commerce in cloth, mobile phones, milk, laundry products, anything that will sell in general.  And I very often place orders for these good with wholesalers in Thiès.  I rarely sell at the retail level.  How did you choose this line of work? -    Madame Aïssatou :  I saw that people were active in this trade, and it was much easier to do.  It doesn't require much schooling.  And so, my peers have pushed me into it. What are the most important aspects of this work? -    Madame Aïssatou :  Getting supplies.  This is why I supply myself quite often from Nouakchott, the capital of  Mauritania, where goods are less expensive.  What is the purpose of the loan you are requesting? -    Madame Aïssatou : This loan, if you give it to me, will allow me to stock up, to develop my business, and to expand it.  Madame Aïssatou is on her third loan request at this branch office.  She is married and the mother two children. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies of goods for her business

loans.name: Selina

texts.en:
Selina C. is currently in the business of selling maize flour, beans, etc.  and is requesting a loan to stock onions to sell.  Selina is 38 years old and is married to a husband who is a soldier. She has 5 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock onions to sell

loans.name: Akomakro Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Faustina is thirty-two years old. She is married and has given birth to four children who are between the ages of one and twelve years old. Three of them are currently in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in the community. Her husband is an accountant by profession.

Faustina is a very hard-working woman. She is into trading. She trades in bags of charcoal. She supplies to retailers and food vendors in her community. Charcoal is one of the most common sources of energy for cooking in most communities in the country. Faustina has been trading in the charcoal business for three years and aspires to expand her business. She is also hopeful to give all her children the best education she can afford. Faustina requests the loan to procure bags of charcoal in bulk.

She is the leader of a five-member trust bank group called ‘Akomakro’, literally meaning 'oneness in heart'. The group members are mainly into food production and trading activities. It is the dream of the members of this group to access this loan so as to procure goods in bulk.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal in bulk

loans.name: Gerard

texts.en: Gerard C. is an entrepreneur and a married man. He runs a pharmacy at Yombo Vituka ward in Dar es Salaam. He purchases the business goods from wholesale pharmaceutical shops. He has been in the business for six years and meets his daily family requirements from the business income. He is requesting a loan of T.shs 800,000 to expand the business.

loans.use: To buy more goods to expand the business

loans.name: Khamisa

texts.en:
Khamisa S. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and bread out of her home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Khamisa is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is a policeman. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Manelina

texts.en:
Manelina B. is currently in the business of selling bread and groundnut paste and is requesting a loan to stock rice and beans to sell.  Manelina is 30 years old and is married to a husband who is a policeman. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. 

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock rice and beans to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of a sewing machine and sewing supplies

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en:
Kiden M. is currently in the business of selling rice, onions, etc. at the market and is requesting a loan to stock beans and fish to sell.  Kiden is 28 years old and is married to a husband who is a soldier. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop for her goods.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock beans and fish to sell

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam I. is a small businesswoman. She runs a clothing shop selling various styles of clothes at Yombo Kiwalan ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the business goods from wholesale and retail shops at Karume and Kariakoo marketing city center. She has managed to buy a plot of land for residential house construction at Vituka ward. She is requesting a loan of T.shs. 1,000,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy business goods to meet customer demand

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr: Awa D. est une femme de 57 ans avec une famille et six enfants - 3 garcons et 3 filles. Awa habite dans la ville de Ziguinchor, une grande ville dans le sud du Senegal. Elle est le proprietaire d'un boutique et avec le pret de Kiva elle souhaite renforcer son commerce, notamment les produits alimentaire. Elle achete ses produits sur le marché local appelé Boucotte non loin d'elle. Elle a travaillé dans sa boutique depuis 1995 et avec les benefices elle soutien sa famille et fournir les depenses quotidiennes. Elle aime son travaille beaucoup et elle se réjouit de l'avenir.
texts.en:
Awa D. is a 57-year-old woman with a family and six children:  three boys and three girls.  She lives in the city of Ziguinchor, a large city in southern Senegal.  She is the owner of a store.  With this Kiva loan, she wishes to bolster her business, especially with food items.  She purchases her goods at the local market called Boucotte, not far from her.  She has worked in her store since 1995.  With the profits, she supports her family and covers the day-to-day expenses.  She likes her work a lot, and she is glad about the future.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering her business

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
N. Godfrey is a hard-working businessman of twenty-seven and a permanent resident of Kyotera, residing in Gayaza LC1 Zone in Nabigasa subcounty. He is a married man with one girl child. He has a retail shop business in TDO cell Kyotera which is operated by his wife. The business is four years old. 

He is using the loan purposely to purchase retail items (smearing jelly, Blue Band, cooking oil, dry cells, toothpaste, toothbrushes, salt, sugar, tea leaves, mineral water, and so forth) to expand the shop and also dealing in polythene bags. His future plans and hopes are to create a big grocery store dealing more in wholesale than retail.

loans.use: To purchase retail items (smearing jelly, Blue Band, cooking oil, batteries, etc. and polythene bags for resale

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en: T. Mohammed is a hard-working businessman of thirty-eight, married with four children who are all in school (primary section) and  he  also has four other dependents. He operates a retail shop in Masaka town, Kikubo Buddu plaza. He has been operating this business for over five years. He is using the loan to purchase retail items such as bags, shoes, mirrors, pegs, and so forth hence so as to expand his business. His business dream is to turn his retail business into a supermarket and his personal dream is to educate his children up to university level and also up-lift his family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as bags, shoes, mirrors, pegs, and so forth hence expanding his business.

loans.name: Gift Of Kasina, Kyenjojo Group

texts.en:
Very innovative, K. James went into a brick making business two years ago. Due to the high demand for bricks as building materials by many people, this has always provided a ready market for his stock.

The married father of four children has maneuvered through hard times to provide for his family but still has not lost heart. With this loan, he will be able to purchase good quality soils for making quality bricks to meet his customers’ demand. This will improve his sales and also help him with business expansion.

loans.use: To purchase quality soils for making bricks

loans.name: Cite Group

texts.fr:
CITE est un groupe de solidarité de 08 femmes toutes mariées exceptée Méta T. qui est veuve. Elles sont toutes du même village de NIAFOR dans la région de ZIGUINCHOR, elles sont d'âges très varié (entre 25 ans et 70 ans)

Elles mènent des activités diverses telles que le maraîchage, le commerce d'huile de palme et d'arachides

Le groupe, pour augmenter sa capacité d'autofinancement, a décidé d'adhérer à l'institution de micro-finance de CAURIE-MF en octobre 2002. Elles sont à leur 17ème crédit et n'ont jamais eu de problème de remboursement. 

Le crédit actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des intrants pour faire le maraîchage et pour s'approvisionner en quantité suffisante pour développer un commerce d'huile de palme et d'arachides.

Quant à la présidente du groupe de solidarité Madame Aramata G., elle est âgée de 46 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants en charge. Elle est vendeuse d'huile de palme et d'arachide et son objectif est de soutenir ses enfants sur le plan scolaire, santé et habillement.
texts.en:
CITE is a solidarity group of eight women who are all married, except for Méta T., who is a widow.  They are all from the same village of NIAFOR in the region of ZIGUINCHOR. Their ages are wide-ranging (from 25 to 70).  They operate diverse businesses, such as market gardening and commerce in palm oil and peanut oil.  To increase their ability to self-finance, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution CAURIE-MF in October 2002.  They are now on their 17th loan and have never had a problem repaying them.  The current loan will be used for buying some market gardening supplies and for stocking up sufficiently to develop a business in palm oil and peanut oil.  As for the solidarity group's president, Ms. Aramata G., she is 46 years old, married, and the mother of three children to support.  She is a seller of palm oil and peanut oil.  Her goal is to provide schooling, health care, and clothing to her children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: bolstering the solidarity group's ability to self-finance

loans.name: Expedito

texts.en: M. Expedito is a hard-working businessman of fifty-four, married with four children. He owns a cloth business located on Grant Street, Masaka. He mainly deals in suits, ties and such. He is using the loan purposefully to purchase more items like suits, trousers, ties, and so forth for sale so as to expand his business. His future hope is to expand his business even further.

loans.use: To purchase more items like suits, trousers, ties, etc. for resale

loans.name: Zinunula Community Bank Group, Nansana

texts.en:
The lucrative nature of her oil-selling business in Nansana, Kampala, has got her thinking big. She is looking at a prospective scenario in the future where she will be running her own petrol (gasoline) stations in Kampala.

This is the ambitious story of K. Deborah, a 35-year-old married mother of eight. She has been selling fuel for the last six years and has managed to educate most of her children to university level as a result of this. With her monthly earnings above 50,000 and rising every year, her optimism is justified.

It’s in Deborah’s future plans to expand her business. She envisages a situation where she will be able to run her own fuel pump stations. She plans to embark on this project as soon she gets this loan.

loans.use: To purchase more jerrycans of fuel to sell

loans.name: Annet

texts.en: Nanteza Annet is twenty-four years old, and she is a hard-working businesswoman, married and blessed with two children. She owns a clothing business in Kalisizo town council. Her business deals with clothes for all stages and both sexes. She is using the loan to purchase a stock of clothes for sale. Her future hope is to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase a stock of clothes for sale

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Fatou C. est une femme de 35 ans, marié avec 3 enfants agés 5, 7 et 12. Elle habite au Ziguinchor, une tres belle ville dans le sud de Senegal. Pour les 6 dernières années, elle a élevé les poussins chez elle. Son entreprise va bien et elle a décidé de prendre son premier prêt pour augmenter ses revenus. L'élevage de poulets est considéré un peu risqué au Sénégal, mais avec 6 ans d'expérience Fatou se sent très à l'aise avec son travail. Elle achète ses poussins pour environ 50 cents et les vend pour $5. Les bénéfices vont vers sa famille et dans un compte d'épargne à IMCEC.
texts.en:
Ms. Fatou C., aged 35, is married and has three children, aged 5, 7, and 12.  She lives in Ziguinchor, a very beautiful city in southern Senegal.  For the last six years, she has been raising chicks at her home.  Her enterprise is doing well, and she decided to take out her first loan to increase her revenues.  Raising chickens is considered rather risky in Senegal.  But with six years of experience, Fatou feels at ease with her work.  She purchases her chicks for about 50 cents and sells them for $5.  The profits will go toward her family and into a savings account at IMCEC. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying chicks to raise

loans.name: Mantelar Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité de MANTELAR est créé en octobre 2002, il est composé de 8membres issus du même village NIAFOR. Le groupe de MATELAR est l'un des 08 groupes qui composent le Banc Villageois de NIAFOR. Les membres du groupe ont en moyenne une quarantaine d'années et sont mères d'au moins 04 enfants. 

Elle font en général du commerce d'huile de palme, d'arachide et du maraîchage. 

Pour intensifier leurs activités et augmenter leur pouvoir d'achat elles ont décidé d'intégrer en octobre 2002 l'institution micro-financier CAURIE-MF pour bénéficier des ses services. Elles ont pratiquement une ancienneté de 8ans et demi dans le système et tous leurs prêts ont été toujours remboursés sans difficultés.

Leurs nouveaux prêts leur permettront de mieux s'approvisionner en marchandises et de développer des activités maraîchères. 

La responsable du Groupe, Fanda toumane N. est âgée de 43 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants en charge et tutrice d'un autre enfant de son beau frère. Elle fait la culture de la patate douce, du commerce d'arachide et d'huile de palme.

Son objectif est de soutenir son mari dans les différentes charges financières de la maison et de participer au payement de la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
The solidarity group MANTELAR was estabished in October 2002.  It is composed of eight members from the same village of NIAFOR.  The group is one of eight groups that make up Banc Villageois de NIAFOR.  The group members average about 40 years of age and are the mothers of at least four children.  In general, their commerce involves palm oil, peanut oil, and market gardening.   To intensify their businesses and to increase their buying power, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution CAURIE-MF in October 2002.  The purpose was to receive some of its services.  They have practically 8½ years of seniority in the system.  Their loans have always been repaid without difficulties.  Their new loans will enable them to do better in supplying themselves with goods and in developing their market garden businesses.  The supervisor of the group, Fanda Toumane N., is 43 years old.  She is married and the mother of six children to support, and she is the guardian of another child of her brother-in-law.  Fanda grows sweet potatoes and sells peanut oil and palm oil.  Her goal is to support her husband in paying for the various house expenses and to take part in covering the children's schooling costs. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: bolstering the goupe's ability to stock up on goods

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase additional general store merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy inventory

loans.name: Karamo Group

texts.fr:
Le Banc Villageois de NIAFOR est un groupe féminin composé de personnes issues toutes du même village. Un village situé environs à 90 kilomètre de la ville de Ziguinchor. Le Groupe de solidarité KARAMO créé en octobre 2002, fait partie de l'un des 8 qui composent ledit Banc Villageois. Les femmes membres du groupe de solidarité sont moyenne âgées de 40ans et mère d'au moins de 4 enfants.

La présidente, numéro 03KD3211081038 est âgée de 51 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants en charge et responsable d'un enfant de sa coépouse. C'est une femme très engagée et qui cultive l'esprit de solidarité dans le groupe. Elle développe un petit commerce de poisson frais, d'huile de palme, de balais faits de feuilles de palmes. Par ailleurs, elle fait également du maraîchage et son objectif est d'améliorer les conditions de santé et alimentaire de sa famille 

Le groupe reste très solidaire lors des remboursement de prêts, ce qui fait que jusqu'à présent, aucun retard de payement n'a été enregistre en leur sein.
texts.en:
The Villager Bank of Niafor is a female group made up of people from the same village. The village is located about 90 km from the town of Ziguinchor.The Mutual Group Karamo, established in October, 2002 forms part of one of the 8 groups which make up the aforementioned Villager Bank.The female members of this mutual group have an average age of 40 years and are the mothers of at least 4 children. The chairwoman, number 03KD3211081038 is 51 years old, married, and the mother of 2 children. She takes care of and is responsible for the child of her co-wife. She is very engaged and cultivates the spirit of solidarity in the group. She does petty trading of fresh fish, palm oil, and brooms made of plam branches. She also equally does truck farming and her goal is to improve the health and feeding conditions of her family. The group remains united during payment of loans which indicates that, until now, no late payment has been registered from their part.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Develop and promote the commercial activities of the group

loans.name: Edy Juan

texts.es:
Edy A. de 37 años vive en una zona periurbana en el Paraíso (llamado así por sus abundantes lomas y montañas sus calles son de tierra y la mayoría de casas son de caña) de Guayaquil. Su esposa es ama de casa pero a sus conocidos les vende cosméticos, ellos tienen tres hijos de 13, 11, 4 años de edad. 

El papa de Edy tenia un taller electrónico donde hacia arreglos de televisores, radios y otros aparatos eléctricos, a Edy desde pequeño empezó a interesarle lo que el papa hacia, cuando el llegaba de la escuela y después de terminar sus deberes el se quedaba en el taller aprendiendo todo lo que el papa hacia mientras que los otros niños estaban jugando. Fue cuando se caso que construyo su casa y la parte delantera la readecuo de madera y caña para poner hay su taller electrónico. 

Por esa buena decisión ahora el tiene un taller de electrónica, trabaja desde las 08h00 am hasta las 18h00 pm todos los días. Su hijo de 13 años también le ayuda en el taller cuando llega de clases. Con el préstamo quiere comprar cables integrados y filtros para utilizarlos en su negocio. 

En el futuro el quiere comprar un carro para transportar los televisores, radios y artículos electrónicos que arregla.
texts.en:
Edy A. is 37 years old and lives in a semi-urban area in Paraiso (Paradise--called that due to its many hills and mountains and the dirt street and homes made of reeds) de Guayaquil. His wife is a homemaker who also sells cosmetics to her neighbors; they have 3 children who are 4, 11, and 13 years old. Edy's father had an electronics workshop where he fixed TVs, radios, and other electric appliances. At a young age, Edy became interested in what his father was doing and when he'd get home from school, he would finish his chores then stay in the workshop to learn everything his father knew while other kids would be playing. When he got married, he built his house and made the front portion into his own electronics workshop. Due to this good decision, he now has his own electronics workshop where he works from 8 am to 6 pm every day. His son is 13 years old and helps him with the work when he gets home from school. He will use the loan to buy cables and filters to use in his business. In the future, he'd like to buy a car to transport the TVs, radios and other appliances that he fixes.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Filters and integral cables

loans.name: Gaburira Women Group, Ntungamo

texts.en:
Very ambitious T. Monic, married with six children, ventured into her business selling paraffin (kerosene) in 2007 in Kyempene Trading centre, Ntungamo district. She was introduced into this business by a friend who had researched it and found it to be very profitable. Since most villages in Uganda are not supplied with electricity, people use pressure lamps and cooking stoves, both requiring paraffin to be put to use.

Monica earns a profit of 105,000 shillings on a weekly basis and, with this loan, her mission is to expand her business by investing in paraffin pumps. These will replace the plastic tanks she has been using which are more risky as she keeps them in her living room.

loans.use: To purchase a fuel tank and pumps to expand her business

loans.name: Kipmutai

texts.en:
Kipmutai is 24 years old and single. He is a dedicated young farmer from Western Kenya near Kitale town. He has been farming for 2 years and owns a kiosk where he sells his vegetables to the local people. He also earns income from a tree nursery business where he sells his tree seedlings of blue cypress to the local market. His main challenge in the farming business has been the high competition in the market and lack of capital for the project.

He has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo for KES.20,000 to start a poultry project. He is confident that this loan will build a strong foundation economically before he starts a family. In future, he would like to acquire his personal farm in order to expand his farming.

loans.use: To start a poultry project

loans.name: Francisco Tito

texts.es:
Francisco S. de 59 años, vive en una zona urbana en el Suburbio (está situado al sur de Guayaquil y generalmente vive gente de clase baja) de Guayaquil. Su esposa es ama de casa, ellos tiene dos hijos de 29 y 20 años de edad. 

Francisco desde pequeño le llamo la atención las cámaras fotográficas, pero por la falta de dinero no pudo comprar una, al crecer  obtuvo su primer trabajo y su primer sueldo compro una cámara. Empezó a tomar fotos a sus vecinos y amigos, pero como necesitaba especializarse, comenzó a estudiar fotografía. 

Por haber estudiado fotografía obtuvo muchas amistades que le ayudaron a ser un fotógrafo profesional. Ahora esa es su actividad principal y así mantiene a su familia, revela las fotos en un cuarto que tiene en su casa, trabaja en eventos sociales y por contrato. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar rollos y pilas para sus cámaras y poder tener mas ingresos para asegurar la vejez de el y su esposa. En el futuro quiere un local propio para tener un estudio de fotografía.
texts.en:
Francisco S., 59, lives in an urban zone in El Suburbio (located in south Guayaquil and generally inhabited by low-income people), Guayaquil. His wife is a housewife and they have two children who are 29 and 20 years of age. Since he was little he’s always been interested in cameras but due to lack of funds was never able to buy himself one. When he grew up and had his first job he used his first salary to buy a camera. He started to take pictures of his neighbors and friends but, because he needed to specialize, he started to study photography. Studying photography led to many friendships that helped him become a professional photographer. Now, this is his main economic activity and how he supports his family. He develops the film in a room in his house and works social events or by contract. He will use the loan to buy rolls of film and batteries for his cameras so that he will earn higher income to insure his and his wife’s old age. In the future, he’d like to have his own place to install his photography studio.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For rolls of film and batteries.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow and construct a dairy unit

loans.name: Allah Is Good Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Adiza is an intelligent 38-year-old woman.  She has three children ranging from 5 months to 18 years old.  Adiza’s husband is an electrician. For the past 10 years, Adiza has sold 'minerals' (soft drinks), pastries, and toffees.  Adiza will use the loan to buy more minerals (soft drinks) and pastries.  Adiza hopes to eventually buy a large refrigerator so she can make more pastries and sell them wholesale.  Her future goal is also to provide her children with quality education.  

Adiza is the leader of the trust bank group called 'Allah Is Good'.  There are 5 members in this group.  The other group members are local restaurant operators, petty traders, and dealers in soft drinks and clothing.  They plan to use the loan to purchase assorted stocks to grow their businesses so they can adequately support their families.

loans.use: To purchase assorted soft drinks in bulk

loans.name: Zakayo

texts.en:
Zakayo is 49 years old and married with 3 children, aged between 3 to 15 years old. Two of the children are currently attending school. Zakayo is a mixed farmer from Western Kenya in Kitale town. He has been farming for 15 years and has been able to employ 3 workers to help him with the farm work. His main produce is maize, vegetables, and milk which he sells on the local market. Zakayo owns some rental houses in Kitale and also earns income from bricks that he sells to the locals.

Zakayo has successfully completed two loans from Juhudi Kilimo for KES.30,000 and KES.45,000. He has requested this third loan from Juhudi for KES.46,800 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that the income from this loan will help him educate his children by paying their school fees and buying them books. In five years' time, Zakayo hopes to be the main supplier of milk to the Kenya Cooperative Creameries in Kitale town. He says that this loan will enable him to expand his dairy farming and take better care of his family as well.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Bariétou

texts.fr: A. D. Bariétou et née en 1970 à Bassila, dans le nord du Bénin. Mariée à YACOUBOU Mohamed, un commerçant, Bariétou est mère de deux enfants. Deux autres enfants sont à la charge du couple. Seulement certains des enfants sont scolarisés. Bariétou et sa famille vivent au quartier Suru Léré à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a près de onze ans que Bariétou s’est installée dans ce quartier. Bariétou n’est jamais allée à l’école. Pour assurer ses différents besoins, Bariétou vend du charbon de bois à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Bariétou vend également de la nourriture. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Bariétou désire élever davantage le niveau de son activité et accroître sa clientèle. Mais Bariétou manque de moyens financiers pour satisfaire sa clientèle. C’est la raison pour laquelle Bariétou sollicite un sixième prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Bariétou A. D. was born in 1970 in Bassila, located in northern Bénin. Married to Mohamed Yacoubou, a merchant, Bariétou is the mother of two children. Two other children are also cared for by the couple. Only some of the children attend school. Bariétou and her family live in the Suru Léré neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capitol of Bénin. It has been close to eleven years since Bariétou moved to this neighborhood. Bariétou never attended school. To provide for her various needs, Bariétou sells wood charcoal from her home. As a secondary form of income, Bariétou also sells food. She is a longstanding client of ALIDé who always repays her loans. Bariétou would like to heighten the standards of her business and increase her cliental, but currently lacks the financial means to satisfy her customers. It is for this reason that Bariétou is seeking her sixth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Colleen Creegan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bags of wood charcoal

loans.name: Stellah

texts.en:
Stellah is 24 years old and married with 2 children aged 2 and 5. The elder child is currently attending school. Stella is a dairy farmer from Western Kenya near Kitale town. She has been farming for 4 years and selling her milk on the local market. She also earns income from the sale of eggs at an open air market in the village. Her main challenge in this business has been lack of a good milk storage apparatus and this has led to her milk going bad.

She has requested this loan from Juhudi KiL. for KES.20,000 to start a poultry project. The income from this loan will help her provide for her family and she will use part of the produce (eggs) for domestic consumption. In future she would like to acquire a motor vehicle to assist in transportation since her business will have expanded.

loans.use: To start a poultry project

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a hard-working farmer from Western Kenya in Kitale town. He is 31 years old and married, with 3 children aged 7 to 12 years old. All the children are currently attending school. He has been practising mixed farming for the last 8 years, producing maize, vegetables and tomatoes which he sells on the local market. He also earns some income from a tailoring business and transport services he offers with his motorbike. His biggest challenge in this farming business has been the high cost of fertilizers which has led to poor harvests.

John has successfully completed his second loan from Juhudi Kilimo for KES.40,000. He has requested this new loan from Juhudi for KES.40,000 to expand his poultry project and construct a cattle shed. He says that he has managed to acquire a dairy cow with the previous loan he was given and has been able to support his family with the income from that loan. He intends to have two more dairy cows that will increase his milk production so he will be able to supply milk to the Kenya Cooperative Creameries.

loans.use: expand his poultry project and construct a cattle shed

loans.name: Women Of Substance Group

texts.en:
Mama P. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'Women Of Substance'.  She is 40 years old, married, and has five children who range from 6 to 16 years old.  She never had the opportunity to attend school.

For 25 years, she has been selling dried fish at the Fiamah Market on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She sells in a friendly manner which keeps customers returning.  

She plans to use her 18,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 92,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more fish. Her goal is to grow her business and to continue to support her children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Mama is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more fish

loans.name: Yesu Ne Hene Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Victoria is a 40-year-old woman who describes herself as enterprising.  Victoria’s husband is a farmer and together they have 5 children between the ages of 6 and 22.  Victoria would like to give her children access to quality education. 
  
For the past 5 years, Victoria has operated a soap manufacturing business.  She will use the loan to buy caustic soda, vegetable oil and perfume for soap making.  Victoria hopes to eventually expand her operations so that she can reach more customers.  In addition to her soap manufacturing business, Victoria helps her husband with farming as well.  

Victoria is the leader of the trust bank group named “Yesu Ne Hene”, which means 'Christ is Lord' in Twi, the language most commonly spoken in Ghana.  There are 17 members in this group.  The group is all women except for one man.  The other members in this group operate retail businesses selling items such as plantains, cooked rice, onions, maize, beans and clothing.   They plan to use the loan to buy assorted inventory to grow their businesses and enrich their familes' living conditions.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for soap-making in bulk

loans.name: Jeanne Dohoué

texts.fr: H. Jeanne Dohoué est née le 08 Mars 1959 et vit depuis près de vingt ans au quartier Midombo à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Jeanne Dohoué est mariée à DAMISSI Damien, un commerçant, et est mère d'un enfant qui est scolarisé. Le couple a un autre enfant à leur charge, en plus de leur enfant. La famille vit ensemble à Midombo. Jeanne Dohoué vient en aide à son mari et assure avec lui les différentes charges de la famille. Depuis une quinzaine d'année, Jeanne Dohoué mène comme activité, la vente de sacs de jute à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est aussi à Dantokpa que Jeanne Dohoué s'approvisionne. Jeanne Dohoué est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà obtenu cinq prêts qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Jeanne Dohoué voudrait rehausser le niveau de son activité et acheter désormais ses produits en gros ; ce qui lui permettra de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et de se faire plus de revenu. C'est pour cette raison que Jeanne Dohoué sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un sixième prêt.
texts.en:
Jeanne Dohoué H. was born on March 8, 1959 and has lived for nearly twenty years in the neighborhood of Midombo in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Jeanne Dohoué is married to Damien Damissi, a trader, and is the mother of one child, who is currently in school. The couple has another child under their care, in addition to their own. The family lives together in Midombo. Jeanne Dohoué comes to the aid of her husband and, with him, provides for the family expenses. For fifteen years, Jeanne Dohoué has sold bags of jute in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. It is also in Dantokpa that Jeanne Dohoué buys her stock. Jeanne Dohoué is a veteran client of ALIDé, having already obtained five loans, which she has fully repaid. Jeanne Dohoué would like to take her business to the next level and to buy her products in bulk from now on. This will enable her to better satisfy her clientele and to encourage more returning customers. It is for this reason that Jeanne Dohoué comes before ALIDé to ask for her sixth loan.

Translated from French by Carolyn McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying bulk bags of jute

loans.name: Aladino Alberto

texts.es:
Aladino G. de 56 años, vive en una zona periurbana en el Fortín de Guayaquil, su casa es de cemento y caña solo cuenta con luz y agua como servicio básico. Su esposa es ama de casa pero también vende cosméticos. Ellos tienen dos hijos de 15 y 12 años. 

El papa de Aladino tenia una carnicería en la ciudad de Cuenca (Está situada en la parte meridional de la Cordillera andina ecuatoriana; es la tercera ciudad de mayor importancia en el Ecuador y se caracteriza por mantener la tranquilidad y hermosura de una ciudad antigua), pero cuando Aladino creció se fue a vivir a la ciudad de Guayaquil, con sus ahorros compro carnes y alquilo un pequeño local para su carniceria. 

Por seguir los pasos de sus padres ahora el tiene una carnicería, vende pollos, carnes, pescados y embutidos. Trabaja desde las 06h00 am hasta las 17h00 pm todos los días. Con el préstamo quiere comprar carnes, pollos, embutidos para su negocio. 

En el futuro quiere comprar una maquina fileteadora para mejorar la atención hacia sus clientes.
texts.en:
Aladino G., 56, lives in a periurban area in El Fortín, Guayaquil; his house is cement and has electricity and running water. His wife is a housewife but she also sells cosmetics; they have two children who are 15 and 12 years of age. Aladino’s father had a butcher shop in Cuenca (Cuenca is in the southern Ecuadorean Andes and is Ecuador’s third most important city; it’s noted for its tranquility and its old city charm). When Aladino grew up, however, he moved to Guayaquil and used his savings to buy meats and to rent a small space for his butcher shop. By following in his parents’ footsteps he how has a butcher shop where he sells chickens, meats, fish and cured meats. He’s open for business from 6am until 5pm every day. He will use the funds to buy meats, chicken and cured meats for his shop. In the future he would like to buy an electric slicer to provide better customer service.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For meats, chicken and cured meats.

loans.name: Allah Wahid Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Alimatu S. is a 42-year-old woman who describes herself as punctual and hard-working.  She is married and has 2 children, ages 20 and 23. Alimatu’s husband is a taxi driver.  She would like to help her children gain a university education.

Alimatu has been a retail seller of undergarments for the past 7 years.  She will use the loan to buy more undergarments like panties, singlets, and boxer shorts as well as skirts and tops.  She hopes to eventually expand her business and supply more items to her customers.

Alimatu is currently the leader of the trust bank group called “Allah Wahid" in Arabic.  There are 13 members in this group.  The other group members also operate retail businesses selling items such as foodstuffs, second-hand clothes, and honey.  They plan to use the loan to buy inventory to grow their businesses and to enable them to take care of their respective families.

loans.use: To purchase underwear, skirts and tops in bulk

loans.name: Talaneh-Su Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the “Talaneh-Su” group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, in order to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each one in the group.
