With the help of this loan, they will be able to buy more goods, make more sales, and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Thirty-two-year-old Isha M. is the leader of this group. Isha, who was born in Kabala town in northern Sierra Leone, is married to a teacher and they have three children. For five years now, Isha has been a businesswoman; she sells rice. With the help of this loan, Isha will be able to buy more bags of rice to add to her business inventory.

loans.use: Buy bags of rice to add to her business inventory

loans.name: Francis V.'s Group

texts.en:
These are teachers at a secondary school in Grafton, near Freetown. This school was opened in 2005 by the Sierra Leone International Mission (SLIM) to educate the children of Grafton, especially children affected by the war. Currently, the school is staffed with four teachers on its payroll and three SLIM-assisted teachers. The school has a population of 116 pupils.  

This group of teachers has come to SMT, a partner of "Shine on Sierra Leone" in Waterloo, to seek a loan in order to supplement their monthly salaries.  With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise not have been able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Francis V. B. (pictured left) is the head teacher at the school and leader of this group of borrowers. Forty-five-year-old Francis was born in Kailahum, eastern Sierra Leone. He is married to a businesswoman and they have five children – two in secondary school and three in primary school. 

In addition to his teaching profession, Mr. B. also does some petty trading. He has been a petty-businessman for over fifteen years (even before joining the teaching profession).  Francis has applied for a loan of SLL 800,000. With this loan, he will buy gallons of palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil) to add to his business inventory.

loans.use: Buy gallons of palm-oil to add to his business inventory

loans.name: Women Of Opportunity Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “Women of Opportunity” group. They are local entrepreneurs in Waterloo, a small town near Freetown, where “Shine on Sierra Leone” has partnered with SMT to start a branch.  They have applied for their first SMT/Kiva loan. With the help of this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their business inventories, make more sales and consequently improve their standard of living. They are requesting a loan of SLL 500,000 for each in the group in order to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Their leader is Rosaline F. (pictured second from right). She is 33 years old. Rosaline owns a beauty salon where she plaits and also sells artificial hair and cosmetics. Rosaline has earned six years of working experience in the hairdressing business.  With her share of the loan, she will buy dozens of artificial hair to add to her business. 

Rosaline was born in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. She is married and the couple has two children; one of their children is in Junior Secondary School I (JSS I) and the other is in class VI.

loans.use: Buy dozens of artificial hair to add to her business

loans.name: Dim Din Group

texts.en:
Meet with members of “Dim Din” group. They are local entrepreneurs in Waterloo, a small town near Freetown, where “Shine on Sierra Leone” has partnered with SMT to start a branch.  They have applied for their first SMT/Kiva loan. With the help of this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their business inventories, make more sales and consequently improve their standard of living. They are requesting a loan of SLL 500,000 for each in the group in order to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Their leader is Haja K. (pictured left). She is 29 years old. Haja sells palm oil (the most popular cooking oil) and peppers. She has been a businesswoman for ten years now. With her share of the loan, she will buy gallons of palm oil and bags of peppers to add to her business.  

Haja was born in Freetown, the capital city of Sierra Leone. She is married to a building contractor and they have three children; one of their children is in class II, the second is in nursery school, and the youngest is not of school going age. 

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Buy gallons of palm oil and bags of peppers for resale

loans.name: To Me To You Group

texts.en:
This group is named “To Me To You”. The members are all local entrepreneurs in Waterloo, a small town near Freetown, where “Shine on Sierra Leone” has partnered with SMT to start a branch.  With the help of this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their business inventories, make more sales and consequently improve their standard of living. They are therefore requesting a loan of SLL 800,000 for each in the group in order to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Their leader is Abibatu K. who is pictured right. Abibatu sells cloth and has been doing this business for more than fifteen years now. She will use her share of the loan to buy bales of cloth (cottons) to add to her business.  

Abibatu was born in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. She is married and the couple has two children – one in class one and the other in nursery school. 

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Buy bales of cloth

loans.name: Tamthekeh Group

texts.en:
This group is named “Tamthekeh”. The members are all local entrepreneurs in Waterloo, a small town near Freetown, where “Shine on Sierra Leone” has partnered with SMT to start a branch.  This will be their first Kiva loan through SMT.  With the help of this loan, they will be able to add more goods to their business inventories, make more sales and consequently improve their standard of living. They are therefore requesting for a loan of SLL 1,700,000 for the entire group in order to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Their leader is 31-year-old Mariatu I. J. (pictured second from left) who sells oil, flour, sugar, rice, Maggi cubes (used to give sauce a sweet taste) and other market-foods. She has been a businesswoman for ten years now. Mariatu will use her share of the loan to buy sugar, oil, Maggi cubes, etc. wholesale to add to her business inventory.  

Mariatu was born in a place called Rotufunk in southern Sierra Leone. She is married to a building contractor and they have two children – one in class six and the other is not of school-going age.

loans.use: Buy sugar, oil, Maggi cubes, etc. wholesale for resale

loans.name: Brima M.'s Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are teachers from a primary school in Waterloo, a small town about 26 miles away from Freetown, Sierra Leone’s capital city.  This school was established in 1996. Currently, the school has 14 staff members.  School staff members from this institution, like many other schools' staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise not be able to accomplish with their mere salaries alone. But with the help of this loan, some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy pieces of furniture, a plot of land, house-building materials, or invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Twenty-eight-year-old Brima M. J. is a teacher at the school and the leader of this group of borrowers. Brima was born in Tombo village, about seven miles from Waterloo. He is married to a hairdresser and they have 2 children – one in class V and the other is in class VI.  Brima has applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 from SMT, a partner of “Shine on Sierra Leone” in Waterloo in order to pay school fees and other school-related charges for his children.

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of a borrower who was not able to be present for the group photo.)

loans.use: Pay school fees and other school-related charges for his children

loans.name: Group For Used Shoes

texts.en:
Solomon G. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'Group For Used Shoes'. He is 40 years old, single, and has three children who range from 5 to 17 years old. He was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to poverty.

For four years, he has been selling used shoes on Mechlin Street downtown Monrovia, Liberia.  He sells in a friendly manner which keeps customers returning.  He plans to use his 9,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 42,800 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more used shoes.  His goal is to grow his business and to continue to support his children so that they can have a better future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Solomon is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more used shoes

loans.name: María

texts.es: María tiene 51 años, es una mujer muy hacendosa, es viuda y vive con su hija en casa de unos parientes. El negocio al que María se dedica, es la venta de condimentos y verduras, por lo que con mucho esmero realiza el picado de verduras y el molido de especias. Su puesto de venta esta ubicado dentro de un mercado de su distrito, por lo que se levanta de muy temprano, a partir de las 6 de la mañana para atender a sus clientes y durante los fines de semana su hija la apoya en el negocio. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo, es picar las verduras uniformemente, ya que considera que la cocina también es un arte, desde entonces ha llevado 8 años realizando esta actividad. Sin embargo para que pueda cumplir con su trabajo y tener los productos listos, tiene que estar desde las 4 de la mañana para comprar la mercadería necesaria en el mercado mayorista de su ciudad. Con el tiempo espera independizarse y pueda ampliar su negocio. Este es su décimo crédito con MFP y afirma que seguirá siendo puntual con el pago de sus cuotas, además se le considera una compañera responsable dentro de su grupo comunal. Con el crédito que solicita,  comprará mayor cantidad de verduras, asimismo desea comprar javas de huevos para complementar con su puesto de venta.
texts.en:
María, 51, is a very diligent woman; she’s a widow and lives with her daughter in relatives’ house. María sells vegetables and condiments so she very carefully chops the vegetables and grinds the spices. Her sales stall is inside one of her district’s markets so she needs to rise very early in the morning and start tending to customers at 6am; her daughter helps her on weekends. What she most enjoys about her work is to chop the vegetables very uniformly because she considers cooking to be an art. She has been in this line of work for 8 years. In order to have her merchandise ready she must start at 4am when she goes to the city’s wholesale market to buy her supplies. She hopes in time to become independent and expand her business. This is her 10th loan with MFP and she affirms that she will continue to be punctual with her repayments. Besides, she is considered to be a responsible member of her communal group. She will use the requested funds to buy vegetables at wholesale as well as crates of eggs to augment the stock items available in her stall.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables and crates of eggs.

loans.name: Misión Impposible Group

texts.es:
María del Rocío Murguía C. tiene 34 años de edad. (En la foto ella viste con una playera rosa y es la tercera persona contándola de izquierda a derecha.)

Ella vive en la comunidad de Santa Bárbara Ixtapaluca, Estado de México.
Es una acredita activa del Grupo Solidario Misión Imposible. 

La señora Rocío se dedica a la elaboración de salsas desde hace 4 años. Esta iniciativa de emprender un negocio se debió a que su esposo no cuenta con un trabajo fijo, solo eventuales y esta situación se dificulta dado que deben cubrir los gastos de sus 4 hijos.

María conoce a  Fundación Realidad  y conversando con sus vecinas, deciden formar un Grupo Solidario para solicitar un crédito.  En el caso de María, este recurso le  servirá para invertir en la compra de desechables por mayoreo para distribuir las salsas y arroz, mismos que se comercializa a través de las tortillerías, de esta manera ella planea obtener mayores ganancias, mismos que le  servirá para la educación  de sus hijos, logrando así una mejor calidad de vida, ella agradece a Kiva la oportunidad de ser beneficiada a través de Fundación Realidad con un crédito.

Las integrantes que conforman el grupo solidario:

María Del Rocio Munguia C.  Vende salsas y arroz.
Maribel S. G.    Vende productos nutricionales.
Veronica A. A.   Es manicurista.
Nancy L. M.  Vende Postres.
texts.en:
María del Rocío Murguía C., 34, appears in the photo wearing a pink t-shirt; she is the third person from left to right. She lives in Santa Bárbara Ixtapaluca, Estado de México and is an active member of the Misión Imposible (Mission Impossible) communal bank. Rocío has manufactured sauces for the last 4 years. She needed to go into business for herself because her husband was unable to find steady employment, he could only land temporary jobs; this situation caused them much stress because they have 4 children to support. María becomes aware of Fundación Realidad and, together with some neighbors, decides to form a communal bank and apply for a loan. In María’s case it will make it possible for her to buy disposable items at wholesale to use for her sauces and rice which she sells through tortilla shops. This way she will earn higher profits that will be for her children’s education thereby attaining a better quality of life. She is grateful to Kiva for the opportunity of being the recipient of a loan through Fundación Realidad. The members of the group are: María Del Rocio Munguia C. -sells sauces and rice. Maribel S. G. -sells nutritional items. Veronica A. Astill -is a manicurist. Nancy L. M. -sells desserts.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for sauces and desserts; nutritional products, manicure supplies, etc.

location.town: Valle De Chalco Solidaridad  Estado De Mexico

loans.name: Luz Y Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El grupo Luz y Esperanza lo integran tres mujeres  trabajadoras, esforzadas  y emprendedoras una de ellas es la señora Rosa Amanda C. R. quien comercializa productos lácteos desde hace ocho años quien recuerda como si fuera ayer como del poco dinero que le quedaba de su salario empezó este negocio el cual con los prestamos ha ido aumentando y mejorando  su negocio.
Esta señora de 38 años madre de dos jóvenes de 20 y 18 y dos adolecentes  16 y 12 años respectivamente  los cuales estudian  tiene el sueño de agrandar su negocio y darle oportunidad a otras mujeres de superarse como ella lo ha hecho.
Sus compañeras de grupo son Martha Francisca M. F. quien en un inicio vendía frutas y verduras pero por medio de los préstamos actualmente distribuye cosméticos y perfumes y Ángela M.  la cual vende granos básicos y realiza reposterías.
texts.en:
The Light and Hope group is made up of three hard-working, enterprising women one of whom is Rosa Amanda C. R.. Rosa has sold dairy products for the past 8 years but remembers it as if it were yesterday; she started the business with the little money she had left over from her salary and with some loans she has grown and improved her business. She is 38 years old and the mother of 2 young adults (18 and 20 years old) and 2 teenagers (12 and 16 years old) who are all in school. She dreams of growing her business and giving other women the opportunity to overcome just as she has. The other women in the group are Martha Francisco M. F. who started selling fruits and vegetables but through loans now works as a distributor of cosmetics and perfumes, and Angela M. who sells basic grains and makes pastries.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cheese, milk, curd, curdled milk, and cream

loans.name: Las Mañanita Group

texts.es:
El grupo las Mañanitas está integrado por tres personas trabajadoras y decididas las cuales han participado del proceso de capación en genero y empoderamiento empresarial. Esto  les ayudado mucho según comento María Elena Velázquez ya que las motivo a progresar e invertir el préstamo adecuadamente.

Velázquez, coordinadora del grupo inicio con una pequeña venta pero luego con los préstamos empezó a distribuir ropa, cosmético, utensilios según le encargan sus  clientes.  Ella con la ayuda de su esposo y su hijo mayor ha logrado abarcar mas mercado y día a día aumentar su negocio.

Sus compañeras de grupo son Ángela Sánchez G. de 70 años quien tiene una tortillería el bastimento por excelencia del nicaragüense y vende frijoles cocidos, y Jeaneth Alejandra V. Rodríguez comercializa ropa desde hace cuatro años.
texts.en:
The Little Mornings group is made up of three hardworking women who have participated in the general training and entrepreneurial empowerment processes. This has helped them a lot according to Maria Elena Velazquez, since it motivates them to progress and to invest their loans in an intelligent manner. Velazquez, group coordinator, started with a small amount of sales, but through loans has begun to distribute clothing, cosmetics, and utensils which her customers have requested. With the help of her husband and oldest son, she has covered a larger market and increased her sales. The other group members are Angela S. Garcia who is 70 years old who has an excellent Nicaraguan tortilla shop and sells cooked beans; and Jeaneth Alejandra V. R. who has sold clothing for the past four years.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Clothing and cosmetics

loans.name: Develop Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Patience is a 59-year-old who describes herself as responsible.  She has four children between the ages of 25 and 39. For the past 30 years, Patience has operated a retail business where she sells items such as stoves, powders and body sprays.  She will use the loan to buy more items for her business.  Patience would like to expand her business by opening a store in another town, so that she can sell more items to customers.  She would like to build a home for her family.  

Patience is the leader of a trust bank group named 'Develop'.  There are four members in the group.  The group members trust and love each other.  The other members also operate retail businesses such as selling foodstuffs, maize, and fried fish.  They plan to use the loan to purchase assorted stocks to grow their businesses to enable them to support their families.

loans.use: To purchase stock such as stoves, powder and body spray.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Products like noni and natural oils

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy a chainsaw

loans.name: Juntos Para Triunfar Group

texts.es:
El grupo “Juntos para Triunfar” es integrado por cuatro personas, tres mujeres y un hombre. Los representa doña Remedio H. A., que se dedica a la venta de tacos de asada y campechaneado (carne asada con longaniza), su local lo tiene enfrente de su casa. Doña Natividad, vende frutas y verduras, doña Hermelinda, zapatos de vA. marcas por catálogo que llega a comprar a la ciudad de Villahermosa y don  José del Carmen se dedica  a la venta de plásticos de manera ambulante en su comunidad y las comunidades vecinas.
	
Doña Mello como así la conocen comprará más ingredientes para su venta de tacos como  carne, cebolla, tomate, chile, cilantro, tortilla, refrescos, mesas y sillas. Ella junto con su esposo (aparece en la foto preparando tacos), atiende la taqueria. Ella tiene la confianza que trabajando con esfuerzo y esmero logrará su meta que es tener una taquería  grande en un local establecido en su localidad y que sus hijos puedan estudiar una carrera universitaria.

Este grupo es muy unido de ahí viene el nombre  y sus actividades son diferentes, es un grupo solidario. 

Agradecen el apoyo que le brinda Fundación Realidad y KIVA por ser afortunados de que estén dispuestos ayudarlos para sacar cada uno su pequeño negocio adelante.
texts.en:
The “Juntos para Triunfar” (Together to Succeed) group is made up of four people, three women and one man. They are represented by Remedio H. A. who sells grilled meat tacos and campechaneando (grilled meat with longaniza sausage) from a stand in front of her house. Natividad sells fruits and vegetables; Hermelinda sells various brands of catalogue shoes that she brings from the city of Villahermosa and José del Carmen is a street vendor of assorted plastic items in his and in adjacent communities. Mrs. Mello, as she is known, will use the funds to buy more ingredients for her taco sales like: meat, onion, tomato, chili, cilantro, tortillas, beverages, tables and chairs. She, together with her husband who appears in the photo preparing tacos, tends to their taco stand. She is confident that by working hard and with care she will reach her goal of having a large taco stand in an established local in her community and that her children will be able to study a university program. This is a very unified group, thus their name. Although they have different activities, it is a very united group She is grateful for the support from Fundación Realidad and KIVA; they are fortunate that they are willing to help them each succeed with their small businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For meat, onions, tomatoes, chiles, cilantro, tortillas, beverages, tables, chairs, shoes, fruit, vegetables and asssorted plastic items.

loans.name: Las Cuatro Rosas Group

texts.es:
El grupo Las Cuatro Rosas está integrado por tres féminas trabajadoras, emprendedoras y esforzadas una de ellas es la señora Estela Brenes quien 1995 inicia su negocio de nacatamales con la compra de un cerdo que actualmente gracias a los prestamos ha ido aumentando. Ella tiene siete hijos pero solo uno está a su cargo quien tiene 18 años y está estudiando.

Sus compañeras de grupo son Sonia Polonia F. de 50 años realiza tortillas y sopas los domingos  y Manuela O. R. de 49 años quien realiza manualidades desde pulseras, collares, monederos, bolsos y hamacas. Ellas invertirán en sus respectivos negocios para hacerlos crecer.
texts.en:
The group Las Cuatro Rosas (the Four Roses) is made up of three hardworking businesswomen. One of them is Estela Brenes who in 1995 started her business of making nacatamales (stuffed steamed corncakes) with the purchase of pork. Currently thanks to the loans the business has been increasing. She has seven children but only one is still with her-an 18 year old who is in school. The other members of the group are Sonia Polonia F., 50, who makes tortillas and soups on Sundays, and Manuela O. R., 49, who does handicrafts such as making bracelets, necklaces, coin purses, bags and hammocks. They are going to use the loan to help their respective businesses grow.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients to make nacatamales (stuffed steamed corncakes), principally pork, corn, potatoes, onions, sweet peppers, rice, chiles,  etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy charcoal and corn

loans.name: Las Palmeras Group

texts.es:
El grupo las Palmeras está integrado por tres mujeres trabajadoras una de ellas es Paula F. E. una fémina sencilla y humilde quien hace tres años con unos ahorros compro algunas prendas Romanel las cuales comercializo. Actualmente ella con los prestamos y la ayuda de su compañero de vida su negocio ha mejorado notablemente.

Sus compañeras de grupo son Rosa Esmeralda M. de 39 años quien se dedica al destace de cerdo y Thelma Mercedes Riva quien con ayuda  de su esposo puso el negocio de venta de mariscos y el cual ha ido aumentando.
texts.en:
The group Las Palmeras (the Palm Trees) is made up of three working women. One of them is Paula F. E., a simple and humble woman. Three years ago, with some savings, she bought and sold a few pieces of Romanel jewelry. Currently with the loans and the help of her live-in partner, her business has been growing remarkably. The companions in the group are Rosa Esmeralda M., 39, who works as a pork butcher, and Thelma Mercedes Riva who, with the help of her husband, started a business selling shellfish-and it has been growing.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy Romanel jewelry

loans.name: Merlyn Esther

texts.es:
Merlyn C. Gutiérrez tiene 43 años  vive con sus padres y su hijo de 13 años; ella es una mujer que no se queda quieta en cuanto a   buscar nuevos ingresos y  de capacitarse se trata, asì es  como ha realizado cursos de mercadeo y ventas, peluquera y belleza, preparación de alimentos y elaboración de calzado y de todos ellos obtiene frutos pues genera ingresos como comerciante  de calzado, ropa y accesorios que fortalecen la imagen de damas caballeros y niños y niñas, trabaja la peluquería a domicilio, prepara hayacas, deditos y frituras los fines de semana  ayudada por su mama, elabora calzado cuando le llevan el modelo que sus clientes le piden y también trabaja  parte de su tiempo en una empresa de manera provisional en oficios varios,  donde ha logrado adquirir su clientela que son principalmente empleados de empresas, aunque  también tiene amas de casa, vecinos, amigos y familiares. Últimamente  su hermana que es cliente de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, como le ha ido muy bien con esta organización le recomendó acceder al programa de créditos para que continúe expandiendo su mercado,  asì es como está solicitando una financiación por valor de $ 1.500.000 para comprar ropa femenina y calzado mixto.   
El entorno habitacional de Marlyn es en el barrio José Antonio Galán, Localidad Suroriente de Barranquilla,  caracterizado por la gran alegría de su gente y el espíritu de solidaridad, que demostraron cuando lograron apoyar al gobierno local para la pavimentación de sus calles,a través de recursos obtenidos mediante paseos, bingos, rifas, festivales y otras actividades comunitarias; es justamente en este ambiente, donde Merlyn desarrolla su negocio, que  inició cuando al trabajar en una empresa, ayudaba a su primo a conseguir clientes para   venderle sus  mercancía, allí  observó la posibilidad de un ingreso adicional y empezó la misma actividad vendiéndole a amigas, vecinas e incrementó su clientela ofreciéndole mercancías a todo el que  se le acercara; su primo continuó proveyéndola hasta que ahorró $150.000,que le permitieron negociar directamente con almacenes y bodegas, como hasta  ahora lo hace mediante una sana relación comercial. Ahora su gran desafío es realizar una  expansión comercial sostenida y más adelante su sueño es tener un local donde pueda integrar todas sus actividades  y su meta principal es ofrecerle a Yosimar,  su  hijo, una educación de la más alta calidad y siempre ser su soporte afectivo.
texts.en:
Merlyn C. Gutiérrez is 43 years old she lives with her parents and her 13 year old son. She is a woman who does not stand still as regards looking for new income and becoming qualified, therefore she has done courses in marketing and sales, hairdressing and beauty, food preparation and footwear manufacturing and she has got a return from all of them. Then she earned income selling shoes, clothing and accessories that stregthen the image of women, men and children. She does hairdressing at home, she makes "hayacas" (meat wrapped in cornmeal dough and banana leaves), "deditos" (finger shaped pastries) and "frituras" (fried food) in the weekends helped by her mother. She makes shoes when her customers take her the model they ask her for and she also works part time in a company provisionally in various roles, where she has managed to acquire her cusomers who are mainly company employees, although she also has housewives, neighbours, friends and family. Recently, her sister who is a customer of the Mario Santo Domingo Foundation, as things have gone well with this organization, advised her to access the loan programme so that she can keep expanding her market, therefore she is asking for financing to the value of $ 1,500,000 to buy women's clothing and footwear for men and women. Marlyn lives in the suburb of José Antonio Galán, in the Suroriente de Barranquilla locality. It is characterized by the great joy of its people and the spirit of solidarity that they demonstrated when they succeeded in supporting local government for the paving of their streets, through resources obtained from walks, bingo, raffles, festivals and other community activities. It is in this environment where Merlyn has developed her business, which started when working in a company. She used to help her cousin to win customers in order to sell them his goods, and there she saw the possibility of an additional income and started the same business selling to friends, neighbors and grew her customer base offering goods to all that came near; her cousin continued to supply her until she saved the $150,000 that allowed her to negotiate directly with department stores and local stores, as up until now she did it through a healthy business connection. Now her great challenge is to complete a sustainable business expansion and in the future her dream is to have a local store where she can integrate all her businesses and her main goal is to offer Yosimar, her son, the highest quality education and always be his emotional support.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy women's clothing and footwear for men and women.

loans.name: La Perla Group

texts.es:
El grupo La Perla está integrado por tres personas trabajadoras, esforzadas y emprendedoras quienes se dedican a la agricultura. El coordinador del grupo es Denis Gómez quien desde hace doce años trabaja en la agricultura con la ayuda de sus hijos e invertirán el crédito en insumos para progresar. 

Sus compañeras de grupo son Lucrecia S. quien desde pequeña aprendió a amar la tierra y trabajar en ella  ya que sus padres tenían una pequeña finca y Juana Baldivia desde hace cinco años cultiva. Ellos invertirán en el cultivo aprovechando el invierno.
texts.en:
The La Perla group is comprised of three hard-working and enterprising people who put forth great effort in their agricultural work. Denis Gómez is the coordinator of the group. He has worked in agriculture, with the help of his children, for 12 years. He will invest the loan in supplies in order to progress. Lucrecia S., a colleague in the group, learned to love and work the earth when she was little. Her parents had a small farm. Juana Baldivia, the other colleague, has been a farmer for five years. They will invest in the crops, taking advantage of the winter.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Farming supplies like fertilizer and seeds, etc.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary N. calls herself an honest petty trader who sells ladies' and gents' shoes and slippers and sandals. She is a mother of 3 and married to a porter. Even though Mary has been in her trade for the last 6 years, she has not been able to own a real store which is her dream. It is her wish that lenders who fund her business will be contributing to this cherished dream. Mary hopes to make some savings from this loan towards acquiring a store at Ayijah market near Kumasi and also help her husband pay their household bills.

Mary wishes her family to own a house in future and has started a special joint account with her husband for that project. She says her contribution will only be from income generated from her business not her working capital. She is grateful to all who will help her achieve her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase slippers and sandals in bulk

loans.name: Happy And Unity Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Kwasi is a 43-year-old man, who describes himself as trustworthy and hard-working.  He is married and has 4 children between the ages of 6 and 17. 
 
Kwasi has been a “kente” seller for the past 22 years.  “Kente” is one of the traditional cloths that depict the rich culture of the Asante people in particular and Ghana as a whole.   Kwasi will use the loan to buy more “kente.”  He hopes to one day expand his “kente” business and supply more customers.  Kwasi would also like to help his children further their education. 
 
Kwasi is currently the leader of the trust bank group called 'Happy and Unity'.  There are 10 members in this group.  All group members intend to use the loan to purchase more “kente” cloth to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase kente cloth in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy spare parts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Mmodenmmo Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Abena is a 55-year-old woman who describes herself as hard-working.  She is married and has 8 children ranging in age from 14 to 35 years old.  Abena’s husband is a farmer.   Abena would like to provide quality education for her two youngest children.  

For the past 25 years, Abena has operated a food retail business selling 'kenkey'.  'Kenkey' is a maize-based dough ball that is usually eaten with pepper sauce and fish.  Abena will use the loan to buy more maize to prepare 'kenkey'.  She hopes to expand her business by supplying 'kenkey' to stores in towns such as Kumawu and Abofanso.  

Abena is currently the leader of the group named "Mmodenmmo", which means “hard-working” in Twi, the language most commonly spoken in Ghana.  There are 10 members in this group.   The other members in the group also operate retail businesses selling items such as fresh tomatoes, yams, onions, 'kenkey', rice and stew.  The members in the group live in the same area and trust each other. They plan to use the loan to buy various inventory to grow their business to enable them to better support their families.

loans.use: To purchase maize, fish, and vegetables in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Jah Bless Group

texts.en:
K. is forty-five years old. He is a married man and has six children who are between the ages of ten and twenty-two. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment in their community. His wife sells palm oil.

K. is a hard-working man. He is a trader. He sells plantains and bags of maize. He supplies to food vendors and retailers in his community and nearby communities. He has been in business for ten years and has amassed great experience. K. buys his goods from nearby farming communities. He hopes to put up his own building to house his family.

K. is currently the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Jah Bless’. The group is made up of six members. Some are traders and others are in food production/sales. The group requests the loan to procure goods and raw materials in bulk to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of corn and beans

loans.name: Las Azucenas Group

texts.es:
El grupo Las Azucenas  está conformado por tres personas tres personas trabajadoras una de ellas es Nubia del Socorro García L. de 49 años quien vende tortillas y nacatamales desde hace seis años con la ayuda de su hija. 
Las otras integrantes del grupo son Santos A.  trabaja vendiendo esquimo desde hace 10 años el inicio como repartidos y ahora tiene un pequeño local donde vende este producto y Eduardo E. quien realiza calzado donde su especialidad son las sandalias.
texts.en:
The "Las Azucenas" (The Lilies) group is made up of three hard-working people. One of them is Nubia del Socorro García L., 49, who has sold tortillas and nacatamales (a type of tamal) for 6 years with the help of her daughter. Another member of the group is Santos A., who has sold Eskimo brand ice cream for 10 years by delivering it and now has a small store where he sells it. Eduardo E. is the third member, who makes footwear. His specialty is sandals.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase corn and firewood

loans.name: Independent Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Paul A. calls himself a responsible and serious trader who sells 'kente' cloth at Ampedwee near Mampong. He is a father of 3 and has been in the 'kente' business for 5 years. He has a dream of owning a whole shop at Kumasi market which will serve Kumasi and Accra, the capital of Ghana. He also hopes to pay for his children's education to a level that will allow them to be gainfully employed.

According to Paul 'Independent Group' was formed to access a loan from a financial institution so as to expand their businesses. Other members are into the sale of smoked fish, food, and provisions. Paul was elected leader as a result of his sense of responsibility. The entire group wish to expand their business with this loan.

loans.use: Purchase 'kente' cloth

loans.name: Josue 1.9 Group

texts.es:
El grupo Josue 1.9 está conformado por tres personas trabajadoras, esforzadas y decididas. El coordinador es el señor Marvin Alberto S. Méndez quien tiene un tramo en el Mercado de Masaya donde comercializa huevos por cajilla.

El inicio con este negocio  ya que en la empresa Avícola donde trabajó cargando y descargando contenedores  le propusieron poner un tramo en el mercado de Masaya y que ellos le iban a proporcionar al crédito los huevos para que los vendiera. El actualmente comercializa grandes cantidades y necesita de mayor cantidad de productos además que su costo es menor si se compra al contado.

Los otros miembros del grupo son Luz Marina S. quien trabaja en la compra y venta de artesanías especialmente masetas y adornos de barro y Carlos José M. quien posee una mini-pulpería que está iniciando donde vende especialmente golosinas.
texts.en:
The group "Josue 1.9" is made of up of three hard-working, determined people. The coordinator is señor Marvin Alberto S. Méndez, who has a stretch in the Mercado de Masaya market, where he sells eggs by the carton. He started this business because he worked at a poultry business where he loaded and unloaded containers, and the company proposed that he get a stretch in the market since they were going to offer him the eggs to sell on credit. He currently sells large quantities of eggs and needs a larger quantity of products. His cost is also lower if he pays cash. Another member of the group is Luz Marina S., who works buying and selling handmade goods, especially flowerpots and clay decorations. Carlos José M. is the third member, who has a small general store that he is starting where his specialty is candy.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase eggs

loans.name: Pilar Pascan Group

texts.en:
Pilar P., 32 years old, is from the town of Plaridel. She is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While both members of the group receive an individual loan, they are both responsible for paying back the loan of the other member if she is delinquent or defaults.

Pilar is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Pilar raises pigs to sell. Pilar has done so for over 2 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Pilar joined PMPC to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC which she used to to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. She is requesting her third loan, for 10000 PHP, which she will use to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve her family’s general living conditions.

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

loans.name: Sabougnima Group

texts.fr:
Sabougnima est un groupe de solidarité composé de 07 femmes toutes mariées et ont une moyenne d'âge de 40 ans. Elles résident toutes à NIANFOR, village distant à 90 kilomètres de la capitale régionale (Ziguinchor)elle sont mères d'au moins de 4 enfants.

Leur activité principale est le maraîchage et comme activité secondaire elle font la vente d'huile de palme, de crème glacée et de jus de fruits naturel.

Le groupe de solidarité Sabougnima est l'un des 08 groupes qui composent le Banc Villageois de NIAFOR, il est créé en octobre 2002 lors de l'inauguration dudit Banc Villageois. La plus part des membres du groupe de solidarité ont une très bonne expérience du crédit pour en avoir bénéficier à 17 fois et aucun de leur remboursement n'a jamais fait l'objet de difficulté. 

Le prêt actuel leur permettra de mieux s'approvisionner en intrants agricoles et en quantité suffisante en huile de palme et ingrédients pour la fabrique de crème glacée et de jus de fruit naturel.

quant à la présidente du groupe de solidarité, Madame Fatoumata M., numéro 03KD3211081072, elle est âgée de 43 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 04 enfants en charge. Elle vend essentiellement de la crème glacée et des jus de fruits fabriqués à base de produits locaux. Et son objectif est d'intensifier son activité en achetant un autre réfrigérateur pour la fabrique de ses produits afin de gagner plus de bénéfices et pouvoir participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.   

En plus du remboursement régulier qu'elles, elles arrivent mensuellement a réaliser une épargne d'environs de 25% de leur crédit.
texts.en:
Sabougnima is a group made up of seven women, all of whom are married and around 40 years old. They all live in Nianfor, a village 90 KM from the capital region of Ziguinchor. They are mothers and have at least four children each. Their primary business is market gardening, but they also sell palm oil, ice-cream, and natural fruit juices. The Sabougnima group is one of eight groups who make up the Village Bank of Niafor. It was created in October of 2002, during the inauguration of the Village Bank project. Most of the members of the group have very good credit, having profited 17 times and never having difficulty in repayment. The current loan has allowed them to stock-up on agricultural fertilizers and a sufficient quantity of palm oil and ingredients for making of ice-cream and fresh fruit juices. As for the president of the group, Mrs. Fatoumata M., number 03KD3211081072, is 43 years old. She is married and the mother of four children. She mostly sells ice-cream and fruit juices, made from local ingredients. Her goal is to increase her business by purchasing another refrigerator to make more product in order to earn more profits and be able to improve her family's quality of life. On top of reimbursing their loan regularly, the women earn a monthly savings of about 25% of their funds.

Translated from French by Carolyn McMahon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing the level of investment in the group

loans.name: Leizel Callenero Group

texts.en:
Leizel C., 29 years old and married, is from the village of Barra Puntod. Leizel is the group leader of a 2-member group loan offered by PMPC. While both members of the group receive an individual loan, they are both responsible for paying back the loan of the other member if she is delinquent or defaults.

To make a living, Leizel is just starting her business of selling a variety of different products in the local community.

In 2006, Leizel joined PMPC to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC which she used to to purchase items to expand her product offering. Leizel is requesting her second loan, for10000 PHP, to expand her business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family’s general living conditions.

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in her new business.

loans.name: Lourgen Magsayo's Group

texts.en:
Lourgen M., 30 years old, is from the village of Dimaluna, Ozamis City Misamis Occidental. She is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Lourgen is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Lourgen runs a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. She has just started this business.

In June 2009, Lourgen joined PMPC to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. Lourgen is requesting her third loan, for 14,995 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve her family’s general living conditions.

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy additional products to sell.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es: Nancy tiene 42 años, vive en su casa propia junto a su esposo y sus 2 hijos aún pequeños. Hace más de 10 años, se ha dedicado a la venta de papa, limón, cebolla, ajos, tomate y demás tubérculos. Desde entonces se levanta muy temprano por la mañana atendiendo sus clientes, hasta las 7.00 de la noche que termina de trabajar. Mientras que su esposo la ayuda en el trabajo, aunque a veces se encarga de recoger a sus hijos del colegio y atenderlos. De esa manera pueden ellos progresar y ayudarse mutuamente. Para Nancy, su prioridad es continuar trabajando, ya que de ello depende para que pueda mantener a su familia.  Por ahora su mayor anhelo es tener un puesto dentro del mercado, ya que donde actualmente vende de forma ambulatoria lo que no le garantiza seguridad. Este es su décimo crédito que tiene con MFP, por lo que se compromete nuevamente a ser responsable con el pago de sus cuotas, considerando éste préstamo muy útil en el progreso de  su negocio. Con el crédito que solicita, lo invertirá en la compra al por mayor de tubérculos y verduras, de esa manera aumentar su capital de trabajo.
texts.en:
Nancy is 42 years old. She lives in her own house with her husband and her two small children. For over ten years she has been selling potatoes, lemons, onions, garlic, tomatoes, and other tubers. She gets up very early in the morning to serve her customers. She finishes work at seven at night. Her husband helps her with the work, although at times he gets the children from school and looks after them. That way they can progress and mutually help each other. Nancy’s priority is to continue working because that is how she is able to support her family. For now her biggest desire is to have a stand inside the market. She currently sells as a street vendor, and that does not guarantee security. This is her tenth loan with MFP. Once again she promises to be responsible with all of her payments. She considers this loan to be very useful to the progress of her business. She will use the loan to buy tubers and vegetables. That way she will increase her working capital.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy tubers wholesale

loans.name: Sunnifa

texts.en:
Mrs. Sunnifa E., 58 years of age and a fresh egg dealer, is our featured entrepreneur of this story. She is a widow and a resident of Gango, Ozamiz City.

She is blessed with two children who are now at their adult age. As a sole bread winner, she engaged in dealing of fresh eggs and for 3 years she was able to support herself. At this time she earns an average net income of not less than 5000 PHP a month. Sunnifa also gets support from one of her children.

Sunnifa joined PMPC in 2008. With good character and excellent credit repayment, she has already had four different loans. Her previous loan amount was 13000 PHP and now she is requesting 25000 PHP to add to her capital for her fresh eggs dealing business.

The future net income of this loan will be used to meet her basic and financial needs, loan repayments, savings and for emergency cases. She is hoping that someday she will expand her market to other places outside Ozamiz City.

About PMPC

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: As additional capital for her Fresh Eggs business.

loans.name: Enma Francisca

texts.es:
Enma tiene 53 años, vive en una zona urbana en el suburbio de Guayaquil, hace años murió su esposo y quedo viuda con sus hijos. Vive sola porque ya sus hijos se casaron pero sus nietos la van a visitar todos los días (En la foto aparece con su nieto de 10 años). 

Su esposo era el que trabajaba pero al morir ella se quedo sin ningún ingreso económico, con unos cuantos ahorros que tenia ella compro pollos para vender a sus vecinos y amigos, poco a poco empezó a tener ingresos y compro un congelador porque en su refrigeradora ya no le alcanzaban los pollos. 

Ella continua con el negocio por lo que es el primer ingreso económico que tiene desde que murió su esposo. Trabaja todos los días vendiendo pollos, pavo y carnes. Con el préstamo quiere comprar mas pollos, carnes, pavos para su negocio. En el futuro quiere tener una avícola de carnes, y así poder asegurar su vejez.
texts.en:
Enma, age 53, lives in the urban area of El Surburbio in Guayaquil. Her husband died years ago leaving her a widow with their children. She lives alone because her children are now married. But, her grandchildren visit her everyday. (She appears in the photo with her ten year old grandson.) Her husband was the one who worked. But, when he died she was left without any income. She used the savings she had to buy chickens to sell to her neighbors and friends. Little by little she started to get income. She bought a freezer because the chickens no longer fit in the refrigerator. She continues in the business as it is the first income she has had since her husband died. She works everyday selling chickens, turkey, and meats. She wants to use the loan to buy more chickens, meats, and turkeys for her business. In the future she wants to have a poultry farm to be able to have a secure old age.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Chickens, meat, turkey
